revision.text:
{{Italicize title}} The '''''Accra Evening News''''' was a daily newspaper established in the [[Gold Coast (British colony)|Gold Coast]] (now Ghana) in 1948 by [[Kwame Nkrumah]]. The paper's appearance marked the foundation of the press in the country as a powerful means to mobilize people, and was followed by publication of the ''Morning Telegraph'' of [[Sekondi]] appeared in January 1949, and then the ''Daily Mail'' of [[Cape Coast]]. ==History== The first edition of the ''Accra Evening News'' appeared as a one-sheet paper on 3 September 1948, when Nkrumah was dismissed from his post as General Secretary of the [[United Gold Coast Convention]]. As [[C. L. R. James]] wrote:
"The Evening News sold all copies it could print. It was besieged by news vendors, and the editors of those days claimed that if they had had the facilities to print they would have sold 50,000 copies a day in Accra, a town of 150,000 people, of whom a large proportion was illiterate. Copies were passed from hand to hand. This was the way Nkrumah mobilized the people of the Gold Coast against British imperialism. This was the birth of African freedom."C. L. R. James, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=3rIDAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA7&lpg=PA7&dq=%22accra+evening+news%22&source=bl&ots=orJcu2G8CJ&sig=SWTAGjRDdq4Q_Gt_rCOkjfXTO1M&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDIQ6AEwBGoVChMI6O3gqLbVxwIVx20UCh1Gswrv#v=onepage&q=%22accra%20evening%20news%22&f=false "Kwame Nkrumah: Founder of African Emancipation"], in ''[[Black World (magazine)|Black World]]'', July 1972 (pp. 4–10), p. 7.
The paper became a mouthpiece for the [[Convention People's Party]] until it was banned the following year by the colonial government. ==References== {{reflist|refs= {{cite book|last=Addo|first=Ebenezer Obiri|title=Kwame Nkrumah: A Case Study of Religion and Politics in Ghana|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=xyXZi1nNAGcC&pg=PA87|year=1997|publisher=University Press of America|isbn=978-0-7618-1318-7|page=87}} {{cite book|last=Bourret|first=F. M.|title=The Gold Coast: A Survey of the Gold Coast and British Togoland, 1919-1951|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wgerAAAAIAAJ&pg=PA213|year=1952|publisher=Stanford University Press|isbn=978-0-8047-0640-7|page=213}} }} [[Category:1948 establishments in Gold Coast (British colony)]] [[Category:Newspapers published in Ghana]] [[Category:Publications established in 1948]] {{Africa-newspaper-stub}}

[[File:Astra logo.svg|220px|thumb|The Astra brand logo]] '''Astra''' is the brand name for a number of [[geostationary satellite|geostationary]] [[communication satellite]]s, both individually and as a group, which are owned and operated by [[SES S.A.]], a global satellite operator based in [[Betzdorf, Luxembourg|Betzdorf]], in eastern [[Luxembourg]]. The name is also used to describe the pan-European broadcasting system provided by these satellites, the [[channel (communications)|channels]] carried on them, and even the reception equipment. At the time of the launch of the first Astra satellite, [[Astra 1A]] in 1988, the satellite's operator was known as '''''Société Européenne des Satellites'''''. In 2001 [[SES Astra]], a newly formed subsidiary of SES, operated the Astra satellites and in September 2011, SES Astra was consolidated back into the parent company, which by this time also operated other satellite families such as [[SES Americom|AMC]], and [[SES World Skies|NSS]].{{cite press release|publisher=SES |date=September 9, 2011 |url=http://en.ses.com/4233325/news/2011/7725000 |title=New logo and brand identity presented at IBC in Amsterdam |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926120837/http://en.ses.com/4233325/news/2011/7725000 |archivedate=September 26, 2011 }}[http://www.spacedaily.com/reports/SES_Operates_Under_New_Management_Structure_999.html ''SES Operates Under New Management Structure''] Space Daily. May 3, 2011. Accessed July 27, 2017 Astra satellites broadcast 2,600 [[Digital data|digital]] [[television]] channels (675 in [[High-definition television|high definition]]) via five main satellite orbital positions to [[household]]s across [[Asia]], [[Australia]], [[Africa]], [[Americas]], [[Europe]], [[New Zealand]], [[Middle East]] and [[North Africa]].Veronica Magan [http://www.satellitetoday.com/broadcasting/2016/01/13/ses-tv-channels-grow-by-11-3-percent-in-2015/ ''SES TV Channels Grow by 11.3 Percent in 2015''] Satellite Today January 13, 2016. Accessed December 1, 2016 The satellites have been instrumental in the establishment of satellite TV and the introduction of [[digital TV]], [[HDTV]], [[3D TV]], and [[Hybrid Broadcast Broadband TV|HbbTV]] in Europe. A book, ''[[High Above (book)|High Above]]'', telling the story of the creation and development of the Astra satellites and their contribution to developments in the European TV and media industry, was published in April 2010 to mark the 25th Anniversary of SES. ==Satellites== There are 16 operational Astra satellites, the majority in five orbital locations - [[Astra 19.2°E]], [[Astra 28.2°E]], [[Astra 23.5°E]], [[Astra 5°E]], [[Astra 31.5°E]]. Astra's principle of "co-location" (several satellites are maintained close to each other, all within a cube with a size of 150 kmBains, Geoff "The [[Failsafe]] Family" ''What Satellite & Digital TV'' April, 2012 pp29) increases flexibility and redundancy. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |- !Satellite !Launch Date !Manufacturer !Model !Launch vehicle !Comments |- !colspan="5" |[[Astra 19.2°E|ASTRA 19.2°E]] |Broadcasts 900 channels (511 [[Standard-definition television|SD]], 382 [[High-definition television|HD]], 7 [[Ultra-high-definition television|UHD]]) to 116 million households[https://www.ses.com/our-network/orbital-positions ''Our Network/Orbital Positions''] www.ses.com. Used at 23.5°E pending launch of Astra 3B. Used at 5°E September 2010, pending launch of Astra 4B/SES-4, then moved April 2012 to 108.2°E where, as of November 2013, in inclined orbit.[http://www.ses.com/fleet-coverage Astra 1E in SES fleet information] Accessed November 29, 2013 Moved in February 2014 to 31.5°E pending launch of Astra 5B.[http://www.n2yo.com/?s=23686 Real Time Satellite Tracking And Predictions - Astra 1E] Accessed February 27, 2014 Returned to 23.5°E in February 2015. From June 2015, continuously moving west at approx 5.4°/day. |- |[[Astra 1K|1K]] |November 26, 2002 |[[Alcatel Space]] |[[Spacebus]] 3000B3S |[[Proton (rocket family)|Proton]] |Launched to 19.2°E but failed to reach geostationary orbit, and intentionally de-orbited on December 10, 2002. |- |[[Astra 5A|5A]] |November 12, 1997 |[[Alcatel Space]] |[[Spacebus 3000|Spacebus 3000 B2]] |[[Ariane 44L]] |Formerly known as [[Sirius 2]]. Moved to 31.5°E and renamed Astra 5A on April 29, 2008. Failed in-orbit January 16, 2009 |} ==Manufacture and launch== Astra satellites have been designed by [[Boeing Satellite Systems]] (formerly [[Hughes Space and Communications]]), [[Airbus Defence and Space]] (formerly [[Astrium]]), [[Alcatel-Lucent|Alcatel Space]], and [[Lockheed Martin]]. The Astra satellites within a family are not identical, for example of the Astra 2 satellites; 2A and 2C are BSS [[601HP]]s, 2B is an Astrium Eurostar E2000+ and 2D is a BSS 376. The satellites have been launched by [[Arianespace]] [[Ariane (rocket)|rockets]] from [[Kourou]], [[French Guiana]], [[International Launch Services]] [[Proton (rocket family)|Proton rocket]]s from [[Baikonur Cosmodrome|Baikonur]], [[Kazakhstan]], and ILS [[Atlas V|Atlas]] rockets from [[Cape Canaveral Air Force Station|Cape Canaveral]], [[Florida]], USA. The satellites are launched into an elliptical "temporary transfer orbit" from where they use onboard propulsion to reach their final circular [[geostationary orbit]]s, at nearly {{convert|36000|km}} altitude. Proton rockets fitted with a fourth stage propulsion unit are capable of launching the satellites several thousand kilometres higher (at the closest point of the elliptical orbit) than Ariane rockets. As a result, most satellites launched in this way have to use less fuel to reach their geostationary orbit, increasing their lifetime. ===Sirius and Astra 4A=== The [[Sirius (satellite)|Sirius]] series of satellites (not connected with the North American [[Sirius Satellite Radio]] service) was started in 1993 with the purchase of the [[British Satellite Broadcasting|BSB]] Marcopolo 1 satellite (renamed Sirius 1) by [[Nordic Satellite AB]] (NSAB) for [[Direct broadcast satellite|direct to home]] broadcasts to the Nordic and Baltic regions from the 5° east orbital position. Subsequent satellites launched to this location include Sirius 2 (1997), Sirius 3 (1998) and Sirius 4 (2007) and the position's coverage has been expanded to include Eastern Europe and Africa. In 2000, SES (then SES Astra) bought the 50% shareholding in NSAB owned by Teracom and Tele Danmark and in 2003 increased that holding to 75%, renaming the company SES Sirius AB. In 2008 Astra acquired further shares to take its shareholding in SES Sirius to 90% and in March 2010 took full control of the company.{{cite press release |publisher=SES Astra |date=March 5, 2010 |url=http://www.ses.com/4233325/news/2010/4487003|title=SES ASTRA TAKES FULL OWNERSHIP OF SES SIRIUS | accessdate = January 26, 2012}} In June 2010, the affiliate company was renamed SES Astra and the Sirius 4 satellite renamed Astra 4A.{{cite press release |publisher=SES Astra |date=June 22, 2010 |url=http://www.ses.com/4233325/news/2010/4489346|title= SES SIRIUS BECOMES SES ASTRA | accessdate = January 26, 2012}} The Astra 4A designation was originally given in 2005 to part of the NSS-10 craft (33 transponders) owned by another subsidiary of SES, [[SES New Skies]], and positioned at 37.5° west for broadcast, data, and telecommunications into Africa,{{cite press release |publisher=SES ASTRA |date=February 17, 2006|url= http://www.ses.com/4233325/news/2006/4445997|title= SES Global Africa completes first successful year in African business | accessdate = January 26, 2012}} and in 2007 to part of the Sirius 4 satellite (six transponders of the FSS Africa beam) owned and operated by SES Sirius. From June 2010, the Astra 4A designation has applied to the entire satellite previously known as Sirius 4. ===Failures=== [[Astra 1K]], the largest commercial communications satellite ever built at the time, was ordered by SES in 1997. It was launched by Proton rocket on November 26, 2002. The rocket lifted off as planned and reached its [[parking orbit]] at which point the final stage of the rocket was to initiate a second burn to transfer the satellite to its geostationary orbit. This did not occur and the satellite was released into the parking orbit, making it unusable. The only way to recover the satellite would have been the use of a [[Space Shuttle]], however this was rejected. On December 10, 2002 SES instructed Alcatel Space (the manufacturer) and the French Space Agency [[CNES]] to deorbit the satellite, it broke up on re-entry over the [[Pacific Ocean]]. On January 16, 2009 [[Astra 5A]] at [[Astra 31.5°E|31.5° east]] "experienced a technical anomaly leading to the end of the spacecraft’s mission"{{cite press release |publisher=SES ASTRA|date=January 16, 2009|url=http://www.ses.com/4233325/news/2009/4468235|title=SES ASTRA Announces End Of ASTRA 5A Spacecraft Mission | accessdate = January 26, 2012}} some four years ahead of the spacecraft's expected end of life. Traffic carried by the satellite (especially channels for German cable service, [[Kabel Deutschland]]) was transferred to [[Astra 23.5°E]]. In March 2009, SES (then SES Astra) announced that in April, the [[Astra 2C]] satellite was to be moved from the [[Astra 28.2°E|28.2° east]] position to 31.5° east to temporarily take over Astra 5A's mission until Astra 3B is launched to [[Astra 23.5°E|23.5° east]], when another craft currently there can be released to 31.5° east.{{cite press release |publisher=SES Astra |date=March 10, 2009 |url=http://www.ses.com/4233325/news/2009/4469428|title=SES To Move ASTRA 2C Satellite To 31.5 Degrees East To Support Development Of New Orbital Position | accessdate = January 26, 2012}} The move of Astra 2C was started in May and completed on May 11[http://www.lyngsat.com/headlines.html ''Astra 2C arrived at 31.5 East'']. LyngSat. Retrieved June 1, 2009 with the first transponders coming into use at the new position in the subsequent two weeks. ==Broadcasting statistics== At the end of 2015, Astra satellite broadcasts were received in 156 million households in Europe. In all, 35% of all European TV households receive DTH satellite TV, 26% receive cable TV, 12% receive IPTV, and 27% receive terrestrial broadcasts. With provision via DTH, cable and IPTV, 61% of European TV homes receive TV from Astra satellites. 71% of all European homes that receive satellite TV, receive TV from Astra satellites; and 93% of all homes that receive IPTV or cable, receive TV from Astra satellites.[https://extranet.ses.com/22068151/SatMo-YE15.pdf ''The year in numbers - SES reach by end of 2015''] www.ses.com. Accessed December 1, 2016 ==See also== {{Portal|Spaceflight}} {{Div col|colwidth=25em}} * [[Astra Digital Radio]] * ''[[High Above (book)|High Above]]'' (book) * [[HD+]] * [[List of broadcast satellites]] * [[SES Americom]] * [[SES Broadband]] * [[MX1 Ltd|MX1]] * [[SES New Skies]] * [[SES S.A.]] (operator) * [[SES Sirius]] * [[EchoStar Mobile]] {{div col end}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{Div col|colwidth=25em}} * [http://www.onastra.com OnAstra] - Official consumers/viewers' site * [https://www.ses.com/our-coverage SES fleet information and map] * [http://www.onastra.com/16848621/how-to-receive#! SES guide to receiving Astra satellites] * [http://www.onastra.com/channel-guide/index.php SES guide to channels broadcasting on Astra satellites] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160420141518/http://www.epak.de/en/news/item/86-epak-dsi9-ka-stabilised-antennas-powered-by-astra-connect#! SES first maritime Ka-band service] * [http://www.lyngsat.com/tracker/europe.html Lyngsat frequency/channel list]. * {{satbeams footprint|5908|Astra 1M Ku-band Wide Beam}} * {{satbeams footprint|5907|Astra 1M Ku-band Europe Beam}} * {{satbeams footprint|5641|Astra 1L Ku-band FSS Beam}} * {{satbeams footprint|5666|Astra 1KR Ku-band Europe Beam}} * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070624101728/http://www.orbitalzone.com/videoclips.htm Astra analogue satellite Promo Video clips - Orbitalzone.Com] * [http://www.sesbroadband.com SES Broadband website] * [https://www.ses.com/about-us/companies/ses-techcom-services SES Techcom Services] - Official site {{div col end}} {{SES Astra}} {{SES World Skies}} {{Use British English|date=January 2014}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Ses Astra}} [[Category:SES]] [[Category:Telecommunications companies of Luxembourg]] [[Category:Direct broadcast satellite services]] [[Category:Communications satellite operators]] [[Category:Betzdorf, Luxembourg]] [[Category:Astra satellites| ]]

{{multiple issues| {{Orphan|date=September 2014}} {{Unreferenced|date=December 2008}} }}
The '''COM+ Alliance of Communicators for Sustainable Development ''' (abbreviated '''COM+ Alliance''' or '''COM+''') is a partnership of international organizations and communications professionals from diverse sectors committed to using communications to advance a vision of [[sustainable development]] that integrates its three pillars: economic, social and environmental.
By offering a platform to share expertise, develop best practice and create synergies, Com+ hopes to actively support creative and inspiring communications across the world.
== Goal ==
The goal of Com+ is to provide resources for media, communications professionals, researchers, academics and civil society to learn and exchange ideas on issues pertaining to sustainable development communications.
COM+ has been awarded the worldwide communication of the International Assessment of Agricultural Science and Technology for Development ([[IAASTD]]).
== Founding partners ==
* The British Broadcasting Corporation ([[BBC]]) World Service Trust * Center for Applied Biodiversity Science (CABS) [http://science.conservation.org/ website], the scientific hub of [[Conservation International]] (CI) * The Consultative Group on International Agricultural Research [[CGIAR]] * [[Global Environment Facility]] (GEF) * GlobeScan ([http://www.globescan.com/ website]) * The International Federation of Environmental Journalists (IFEJ) ([http://www.ifej.org/ website]) * [[Inter Press Service]] (IPS) * [[IUCN]] - The World Conservation Union * One Planet ([http://www.oneplanetpictures.co.uk/ website]) * Reuters Foundation ([http://www.foundation.reuters.com/ website]) * Southern Caucus of NGOs for Sustainable Development ([https://web.archive.org/web/20071231072931/http://www.southngocaucus.org/ website]) * [[Television Trust for the Environment]] TVE ([http://www.tve.org/ website]) * United Nations Environment Programme ([[UNEP]]) * [[World Bank]] * [[WBCSD]]
== Associate partners ==
* GREEN ([http://www.green-consultancy.com/ website]) * [[GreenFacts]] ([http://www.greenfacts.org/ website]) * Thomson Foundation ([http://www.thomsonfoundation.org/ website]) * Television for Education Asia Pacific (TVEAP) ([https://web.archive.org/web/20110425014823/http://www.tveap.org/ website])
== External links == * [http://www.complusalliance.org/ The website of the COM+ Alliance]
[[Category:International sustainability organizations]]
{{international-org-stub}}

revision.text:
The '''Dale Youth boxing club''' is an amateur boxing club in London that operated from a gym in [[Grenfell Tower]] on the [[Lancaster West Estate]]. It has produced many champions, but lost its premises in the 2017 [[Grenfell Tower fire|fire]] that destroyed the tower.
==History== Before moving into the [[Grenfell Tower]] the club used a church hall, affectionately called "The Morgue".<ref name=ind/>
Since 1999 or 2000 the club had occupied a {{convert|190|sqm|sqyd|adj=on}} gym on the ground floor in the podium of the Grenfell Tower. During the two-year refurbishment it moved into temporary accommodation in a section of the basement garages of the "finger blocks"; in November 2016 it then moved to a new {{convert|287|sqm|sqyd|adj=on}} venue on the walkway level of the tower.<ref name=ind>{{cite news|last1=Bunce|first1=Steve|title=Lost to the Grenfell Tower flames but the spirit of Dale Youth boxing club lives on|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/sport/general/boxing/grenfell-tower-fire-dale-youth-boxing-club-spirit-perseveres-a7801831.html|accessdate=8 July 2017|work=The Independent|date=21 June 2017}}</ref><ref name="960664.pdf">[https://www.rbkc.gov.uk/idoxWAM/doc/Other-960664.pdf?extension=.pdf&id=960664&location=VOLUME2&contentType=application/pdf&pageCount=1 Grenfell Tower regeneration Project] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170617013611/https://www.rbkc.gov.uk/idoxWAM/doc/Other-960664.pdf?extension=.pdf&id=960664&location=VOLUME2&contentType=application%2Fpdf&pageCount=1 |date=2017-06-17 }}</ref>
Everything was lost in the [[Grenfell Tower fire]] on 14 June 2017, and the club moved back to its former temporary accommodation.<ref name=ind/> Volunteers are helping prepare new premises for the gym and a community centre through the television programme ''[[DIY SOS]]''.<ref name=BBC>{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.com/news/uk-england-london-44125296 |title=Duke of Cambridge joins DIY SOS Grenfell crew |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=15 May 2018 }}</ref>
==Coaches== There have been many coaches over the club's history. Mick Delaney, who runs the club, has been with it since 1978 and Gary McGuiness since approximately 2000.<ref name=ind/>
==Notable boxers== Boxers trained at the club include Olympic gold medal winner [[James DeGale]], super middleweight world champion [[George Groves (boxer)|George Groves]]<ref name=ind/><ref name=BBC/> and heavyweight [[Daniel Dubois (boxer)|Daniel Dubois]].<ref>{{cite news |first=Matt |last=Christie |url=http://www.boxingnewsonline.net/dale-youth-abc-will-rise-again-after-the-grenfell-tower-fire/ |title=Dale Youth ABC will rise again after the Grenfell Tower fire |newspaper=Boxing News |date=16 June 2017 }}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
{{UK-stub}}
[[Category:Boxing clubs in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Gyms in the United Kingdom]]

[[Image:Rød dansk malkerace RDM.jpg|thumb|Danish Red cattle]] '''Danish Red''' cattle, also known as '''Red Danish''' or '''Red Dane''', are a major [[dairy cattle]] breed in northern [[Europe]].<ref>[http://www.ansi.okstate.edu/breeds/cattle/danishred/ Oklahoma State University breeds of livestock]</ref><ref>[http://www.embryoplus.com/cattle_danish_red.html Embryo Plus cattle breeds - Danish Red]</ref> There are 42,599 pedigree cows in [[Denmark]]. They can be used as a beef breed once they finish their useful lifetime.<ref>http://www.vaex.nl/vv/int-eng/cattle/breeding-cattle/dairy-breeds/danish-red.aspx</ref>
== The Breed == The breed was developed in [[Denmark]] based on local breeds bred with [[Angeln cattle]]<ref>[http://www.ansi.okstate.edu/breeds/cattle/angeln/ Oklahoma State University breeds of livestock- Angeln Cattle]</ref> from [[Angeln]], [[Schleswig]]. Danish Red cattle (and, earlier, Angeln cattle) have been imported to many other countries and have been used to improve and form many local breeds,<ref>[http://www.tiho-hannover.de/einricht/zucht/eaap/groups/c4_3.htm EAAP Similar central European breeds ]</ref> such as [[Lithuanian Red]], [[Estonian Red]],<ref>[http://www.embryoplus.com/cattle_estonian_red.html Embryo Plus cattle breeds - Estonian Red]</ref> [[Latvian Red]], [[Polish Red]], [[Belarus Red]],<ref>[http://www.embryoplus.com/cattle_belarus_red.html Embryo Plus cattle breeds - Belarus Red]</ref><ref>[http://www.ansi.okstate.edu/breeds/cattle/belarusred/ Oklahoma State University breeds of livestock- Belarus Red Cattle]</ref> [[Tambov Red]] (Russian Red), Bulgarian Red, etc.
The solid red color of these breeds has helped in making them popular for crossbreeding in tropical countries<ref>[http://www.fao.org/DOCREP/004/X6500E/X6500E13.htm Food and agriculture organisation World Animal Review]</ref> with red [[Zebu]] dairy breeds like [[Sahiwal cattle|Sahiwal]], [[Red Sindhi cattle|Red Sindhi]] and [[Butana cattle|Butana]]. They are good milk cows, yielding milk with higher butter fat and protein content than the [[Holstein Friesian cattle|Holstein Friesian]] does.
==Notes==<!-- Conservation Biology Volume 20, No. 6, 1768–1779 --> {{reflist|2}}
==External links==<!-- Registries and Associations --> *[http://www.dairycattleregistry.com Composite Dairy Cattle Registry, USA]
[[Category:Cattle breeds originating in Denmark]] [[Category:Cattle breeds]] [[Category:Dairy cattle breeds]]
{{Denmark-stub}} {{cattle-stub}} [[Category:Red cattle]]

{{Coord|21|33|33|N|39|11|05|E|display=title}} {{Infobox company| name = Danube Company Limited | type = Retailers | foundation = 1987 | industry = [[Supermarket|Hypermarket]]| location = [[Jeddah]], Saudi Arabia | key_people = Abdul Razzaq Bindawood
({{small|Chairman}}) | owner = Bindawood Group | num_employees = 10,000 [2018, 3rd qtr]| products = Retail - [[Supermarket|Hypermarket]]| homepage = [http://www.danubeco.com/ danubeco.com]| }} '''Danube Company Limited''' is a supermarket and [[hypermarket]] chain in [[Saudi Arabia]]. It opened in 1987, and has operations in the cities of [[Jeddah]], [[Riyadh]], [[Medina]] and [[Mecca]] in Saudi Arabia.{{cite web|url=http://www.me-congress.com/resources/documents/1256742168p.26.pdf|date=28 October 2009|title=Danube shows way in Saudi Arabia|publisher=Eurofruit Magazine|accessdate=2015-04-10}}{{citation needed|date=November 2011}} It is owned and operated by the [[Bindawood Group]] of Companies.BINDAWOOD Group website http://www.bindawood.com/new1/group/index.asp == Branches == Danube opened its first hypermarket at the [[Heraa International Mall]]{{cite web|url=http://www.mecsc.org/newsletter/nledt_view.php?id=43|title=Middle East Council of Shopping Centres - Page not found|author=in1touch http://www.in1touch.com|publisher=mecsc.org|accessdate=2015-04-10}} in 1993. In Jeddah Than the branch moved to a hypermarket about 0.5 kilometres away from Heraa Int'l Mall, Danube hypermakets are located at Medina Road (Originally Heraa Int'l Mall), [[Serafi Megamall]],{{cite web|url=http://uaemegaprojects.blogspot.com/2008/07/serafi-mega-mall-jeddah-saudi-arabia.html|title=UAE MEGA PROJECTS: Serafi Mega Mall, Jeddah, Saudi Arabia|publisher=uaemegaprojects.blogspot.com|accessdate=2015-04-10}} [[Redsea Mall]] http://www.redseamall.com/hypermarket.php and at [[Central Park Mall (Jeddah)|Central Park Mall]]{{cite web|url=http://www.olaat.com/index%20-News.html|title=Olat Development CO.LTD|publisher=olaat.com|accessdate=2015-04-10}}{{cite web|url=https://foursquare.com/v/danube-hypermarket--%D8%A7%D9%84%D8%AF%D8%A7%D9%86%D9%88%D8%A8-%D9%87%D8%A7%D9%8A%D8%A8%D8%B1-%D9%85%D8%A7%D8%B1%D9%83%D8%AA/4de1497ce4cd846e409f0e56|title=Danube Hypermarket | الدانوب هايبر ماركت - الفيحاء - جدة, Minţaqat Makkah|publisher=foursquare.com|accessdate=2015-04-10}} Danube opened its first hypermarket in Riyadh's [[Hayat Mall]]Hayat Mall Website http://www.hayat-mall.com/en/moredreamsAboutUs.aspx in 2006 and built its second at [[Panorama Mall]]Panorama Mall website http://www.zoom-creative.com/clients/panorama-mall/index.html{{cite web |url=http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentID=2010013161854&archiveissuedate=31/01/2010 |title=Danube Hypermarket opens its second branch in Riyadh | Business | Saudi Gazette |publisher=saudigazette.com.sa |accessdate=2015-04-10 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150417165913/http://www.saudigazette.com.sa/index.cfm?method=home.regcon&contentID=2010013161854&archiveissuedate=31%2F01%2F2010 |archivedate=2015-04-17 |df= }} in 2010. Hittin-Exit-2- Riyadh,Al-Kharj,Al-Nakhla Plaza-Exit-8,Riyadh,Yasmeen Plaza-Riyadh,Tellal-Riyadh,Al-wadi Plaza-Riyadh .one new branch opened in jeddah on Thalia street, safa district. == Recognition == Danube was featured in books in 2005 and 2008{{cite book|title=Supermarket & pastry shop design|author1=Al-Hasan, M.Y.|author2=Bindawood Group|date=2008|publisher=Visual Reference Publications|isbn=9781584711513|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oJTzAAAAMAAJ|accessdate=2015-04-10}} == References == {{reflist}} [[Category:Grocers]] {{SaudiArabia-company-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=September 2010}}
'''Evidence Informed Policy Network (EVIPNet)''' is a network, sponsored by the [[World Health Organization]] (WHO), which attempts to improve [[public health]], especially in [[developing country|developing countries]], by coordinating the efforts of policymakers and health researchers.
==History==
EVIPNet grew out of discussions at the Ministerial Summit on Health Research held in [[Mexico City]], November 16–20, 2004. Following the Summit, the [[World Health Assembly]] which governs the World Health Organization passed Resolution 58.2, 4-5 endorsing the "''Mexico Statement On Health Research: Knowledge for better health''" developed during the Summit.<ref>Hamid M, Bustamante-Manaog T, Dung TV, Akkhavong K, Fu H, Ma Y, Zhong X, Salmela R, Panisset U, Pang, T. EVIPNet: translating the spirit of Mexico. The Lancet. 2005. 366(9499): 1758-1760. https://doi.org/10.1016/S0140-6736(05)67709-4</ref> In the statement, [[Health minister|Ministers of Health]] and delegates called "for national [[government]]s to establish sustainable programs to support evidence-based public health and health care delivery systems, and evidence-based health related policies." Resolution 58.34 made a call "to establish or strengthen mechanisms to transfer knowledge in support of evidence-based public health and health-care delivery systems, and evidence-based health-related policies".<ref>[http://www.who.int/gb/ebwha/pdf_files/WHA58/WHA58_34-en.pdf] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090422171533/http://www.who.int/gb/ebwha/pdf_files/WHA58/WHA58_34-en.pdf|date=April 22, 2009}}</ref> Developments relevant to EVIPNet are regularly reported to the Advisory Committee on Health Research of the World Health Organization and of its Regional Offices.
In March 2009 the EVIPNet Secretariat presented to WHO’s Advisory Committee on Health Research a capacity building strategy that assesed through a validated tool the knowledge needs with respect to a defined set of skills for EVIPNet teams, allowing a strategic and organized approach to capacity building.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.who.int/rpc/advisory_committee/en/ |title=WHO | Advisory Committee on Health Research | ACHR |publisher=Who.int |date=2011-07-01 |accessdate=2012-11-10}}</ref> Similarly, WHO Regional Advisory Committees on Health Research monitor progress and provide key guidance to EVIPNet efforts.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://new.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=1842&Itemid=1654&lang=en |title=Advisory Committee on Health Research (ACHR) |publisher=New.paho.org |date= |accessdate=2012-11-10}}</ref>
EVIPNet gained great momentum in Africa where policy briefs soon became available.<ref>Lavis JN, Panisset U. EVIPNet Africa's first series of policy briefs to support evidence-informed policymaking. Int. J. of Tech. Assessment in Health Care. 2010. 26(2): 229-232. https://doi.org/10.1017/S0266462310000206</ref>. The enthusiasm had spread also to the Americas and the Eastern Mediterranean, and after a coordination [http://apps.who.int/iris/handle/10665/204661 meeting organized by WHO in Addis Ababa in October 2015], it gained traction in the European region as well.<ref>World Health Organization. Regional Office for Africa. (2016). EVIPNetAfrica Meeting, Addis Ababa, Ethiopia 14–16 October 2015: Final Report. World Health Organization. Regional Office for Africa. http://www.who.int/iris/handle/10665/204661 </ref> By then, the Global Steering Group working with WHO Collaborating Centers (e.g. [http://apps.who.int/whocc/Detail.aspx?cc_ref=CAN-72&cc_title=who%20collaborating%20centre%20for%20evidence-informed%20policy& WHO Collaborating Centre for Evidence-Informed Policy, at McMaster Universit]y)and specialized centers such as BIREME, the Latin American and Caribbean Center on Health Sciences Information - had set up one-stop shops that enabled access to specialized collections of indexed policy briefs, systematic reviews, policy documents and other relevant resources, as one of the shared resources for the global EVIPNet networks. For example, the free access portals (with registration) of [https://www.healthsystemsevidence.org/ Health Systems Evidence] and [https://www.healthevidence.org/ Health Evidence].<ref>Moat K. A., Lavis J. N.. Apoyar el empleo de investigaciones sanitarias de la más alta calidad (evidencias) en las Américas, mediante un servicio de ventanilla única online: el EVIPNet BVS. Cad. Saúde Pública [Internet]. 2014 Dec [cited 2018 July 27] ; 30( 12 ): 2697-2701. Available from: http://www.scielo.br/scielo.php?script=sci_arttext&pid=S0102-311X2014001202697&lng=en. https://dx.doi.org/10.1590/0102-311x00110214.</ref>
In October 2016 The World Health Organization published an executive summary and document entitled "[http://www.who.int/evidence/resources/publication/en/ Evipnet 10 years 10 stories]" with a selection of cases describing impacts of EVIPNet at country level.<ref>WHO. [http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/250582/1/WHO-HIS-IER-REK-16.03-eng.pdf?ua=1 EVIPNet in action- Executive Summary: WHO. 2016. WHO/HIS/IER/REK/16.03] </ref> <ref>WHO. [http://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/10665/250581/1/WHO-HIS-IER-REK-16.02-eng.pdf?ua=1 EVIPNet in action: 10 years, 10 stories. Geneva: WHO. 2016. WHO/HIS/IER/REK/16.02]</ref>
In the meanwhile, the platform expanded especially in the European region. <ref>Kuchenmueller T, Bekker M,. Workshop: Mapping the European knowledge translation landscape: Insights from five EVIPNet Europe members. European Journal of Public Health, Volume 27, Issue suppl_3, 1 November 2017, ckx187.642, https://doi.org/10.1093/eurpub/ckx187.642</ref>
In November-December 2016, PAHO's [http://www.paho.org/achr/46 46th Advisory Committee on Health Research] convened and its report, issued in 2017, provided updates on EVIPNet and knoweldge translation efforts in the Americas.<ref>Pan American Health Organization. 46th Session of the Advisory Committee on Health Research. (Washington, D.C., 28-30 November 2016). Washington, D.C.: PAHO; 2017. http://iris.paho.org/xmlui/handle/123456789/34305</ref>. The meeting was informed by a preliminary version of a Report on Strengthening Research Capacities in the Caribbean that described EVIPNet related technical cooperation in that region.<ref>Pan American Health Organization. Report on Strengthening Research Capacities for Health in the Caribbean, 2007-2017. Washington, D.C.: PAHO; 2017. Available at http://iris.paho.org/xmlui/handle/123456789/34342.</ref>
In July 2018 The [https://www.bmj.com/health-research-americas BMJ published a special series on the policy on research for health] of the Pan American Health Organization (that applies to the Secretariat and Member States) featuring EVIPNet in the article on [https://www.bmj.com/content/362/bmj.k2469 Advancing public health and health systems through evidence-informed policy in the Americas]. <ref>Pantoja T, Barreto JM, Panisset U. Improving public health and health systems through evidence informed policy in the Americas. BMJ 2018;362:k2469.</ref>.
==Operation==
EVIPNet operated by forming [[country]] or [[region]]al-level teams composed of policy makers, researchers and representatives from other sectors (e.g. science & technology, education, civil society organizations, patient advocates, topic experts, local networks, etc.). These teams identify and address country priority topics where a perceived need to strengthen the systematic use of research evidence to inform decisions about policies for health has been identified. EVIPNet therefore includes components relevant to [[research and development]] and claims to help strengthen national health research systems.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/view_play_list?p=52A099D7FAD58031 |title=Evipnet |publisher=YouTube |date=2011-06-06 |accessdate=2012-11-10}}</ref>
By providing a common purpose to team members EVIPNet facilitates that different sectors jointly address specific priorities and develop and use specific skills to assess research evidence and integrate it into policies. Frequent outputs of EVIPNet teams are policy briefs that integrate evidence with context and values on succinct and helpful documents that inform decisions by high level decision makers. Several EVIPNet teams have already delivered useful relevant outputs such as Policy Briefs and deliverative dialogues that have informed policy at national and local levels.<ref>{{cite web|author=John N. Lavisa1 and Ulysses Panisseta2 |url=http://journals.cambridge.org/action/displayAbstract?fromPage=online&aid=7527836 |title=Cambridge Journals Online - Abstract |publisher=Journals.cambridge.org |date=2010-04-15 |accessdate=2012-11-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://brasil.evipnet.org/ |title=EVIPNet Brasil |publisher=Brasil.evipnet.org |date= |accessdate=2012-11-10}}</ref>
To join EVIPNet country health authorities establish a formal commitment with the Secretariat and develop a work proposal. The Secretariat of EVIPNet is composed by staff from the research policy teams of the [[World health organization|World Health Organization]] (WHO) in [[Geneva]] and its Regional Offices. The EVIPNet Secretariat supports country teams so that they produce robust proposals. EVIPNet has Steering Groups (in the regional and global network) and resource groups in each region. These groups work with experts and networks to provide feedback and expertise to the country teams.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.evipnet.org/ |title=Evipnet |publisher=Evipnet |date=2012-11-03 |accessdate=2012-11-10}}</ref>
The Secretariat works with country teams to identify and address skill needs and deliver targeted capacity building activities in collaboration with networks and partners (e.g. SUPPORT Collaboration, McMaster Health Forum, [[Cochrane Collaboration]], etc.)
==Reception and impact==
As EVIPNet expands and develops it has been highlighted as a worthy approach featured in prominent strategy documents addressing development and capacity building for research for health. It remains relevant as reflected in the call to action issued at the Global Ministerial Forum on Research for Health in [[Bamako]] in November 2008 by ministers and ministerial representatives from 53 countries.<ref name="WHO's Role">{{cite web|url=http://apps.who.int/gb/ebwha/pdf_files/EB124/B124_12Add2-en.pdf|title=WHO's Role and Responsibilities in Health Research|publisher=Apps.who.int|accessdate=2012-11-10}}</ref> EVIPNet was also featured in at least 12 different presentations at the First Global Symposium on Health Systems Research<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.hsr-symposium.org/ |title=Global Symposium on Health Systems Research (HSR) :: Beijing, People's Republic of China, 31 October - 3 November 2012 |publisher=Hsr-symposium.org |date=2012-11-03 |accessdate=2012-11-10}}</ref> ([[Montreux|Montreux, Switzerland]], 2010), and is frequently featured at Colloquiums of the Cochrane and Campbell Collaborations, and Global Forums on Health Research (e.g. Bamako 2008, Havana 2009).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://new.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=2795&Itemid=931&lang=en |title=Strengthening National Health Research Systems |publisher=New.paho.org |date=2012-05-07 |accessdate=2012-11-10}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cochrane.org/events/colloquia |title=Annual Colloquia | The Cochrane Collaboration |publisher=Cochrane.org |date=2012-10-23 |accessdate=2012-11-10}}</ref>
EVIPNet has also allowed for the development of customized resources that have helped advance their work and knowledge about health systems research. For example, the SUPPORT Tools for Evidence Informed Policy Making (available in various languages),<ref>{{cite web|url=http://new.paho.org/hq/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=4468&Itemid=931&lang=en |title=SUPPORT Tools for Evidence-Informed Policy-Making (STP): accessible in four languages |publisher=New.paho.org |date=2012-03-07 |accessdate=2012-11-10}}</ref> the Evidence Portal,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://evidencias.bvsalud.org/php/index.php?lang=en |title=Evidence Portal |publisher=Evidencias.bvsalud.org |date= |accessdate=2012-11-10}}</ref> or the McMaster Database on Health Systems Evidence with >1800 systematic reviews on health systems evidence.
==PAHO/WHO technical programs==
EVIPNet has also become a tool for PAHO/WHO technical programs offering an integrated approach to technical cooperation; in PAHO/WHO research focal points in country offices are part of EVIPNet teams, and technical programs have adopted EVIPNet methods to provide an integrated technical cooperation.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.paho.org/researchportal/EVIPNet |title=Update. Influenza A (H1N1) Regional Report (June 5 2009) |publisher=Paho.org |date=2009-06-05 |accessdate=2012-11-10}}</ref>
==Further reading== #Hamid M, Bustamante-Manaog T, Viet Dung T, Akkhavong K, Fu H, Ma Y, Zhong X, Salmela R, Panisset U, Pang T. EVIPNet: translating the spirit of Mexico. The Lancet. 2005; 366(9499):1758-1760 {{doi|10.1016/S0140-6736(05)67709-4}}<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(05)67709-4/fulltext |title=EVIPNet: translating the spirit of Mexico |journal=The Lancet |date= |accessdate=2012-11-10 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(05)67709-4 |volume=366 |pages=1758–1760}}</ref> #EVIPNet Americas Secretariat, Corkum S, Cuervo LG, Porrás A. EVIPNet Americas: informing policies with evidence. Lancet. 2008 Sep 27;372(9644):1130-1131.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Original TextEVIPNet Americas Secretariat a |url=http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(08)61459-2/fulltext |title=EVIPNet Americas: informing policies with evidence |journal=The Lancet |date= |accessdate=2012-11-10 |doi=10.1016/S0140-6736(08)61459-2 |volume=372 |pages=1130–1131}}</ref> # HM Government. Health is global: a UK Government strategy 2008-13. Annex 1. Strengthening the way we develop and use evidence to improve policy and practice. Page 76.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.dh.gov.uk/en/Publicationsandstatistics/Publications/PublicationsPolicyAndGuidance/DH_088702 |title=Health is global: a UK Government strategy 2008-13 : Department of Health - Publications |publisher=Dh.gov.uk |date=2008-09-30 |accessdate=2012-11-10}}</ref> #World Health Organization, 124th Session of the Executive Board. WHO's Role and Responsibilities in Health Research: Bamako Global Ministerial Forum on Research for Health. Document EB124/12 Add.2. January 2009.<ref name="WHO's Role"/>

[[File:Balliol arms.svg|thumb|Balliol arms: ''Gules an orle argent'']] The '''House of Balliol''' (de Bailleul) was a [[nobility|noble]] family originating from the village of [[Bailleul, Somme|Bailleul]] in [[Picardy]]. They held estates in England, granted during the reign of King [[William Rufus]]. Through marriage, they had [[Competitors for the Crown of Scotland|claims to the Throne of Scotland]]. One member of the family, [[John Balliol]], was named King of Scotland after the disputed succession following extinction of the [[House of Dunkeld|Dunkeld line]]. John was deposed, leading to the [[First War of Scottish Independence]]. His son, [[Edward Balliol]], also briefly controlled the Scottish throne during the [[Second War of Scottish Independence]]. Edward had no issue, and the direct line went extinct with him. ==List of heads of the Balliol estates== * [[Guy I de Balliol]] (died before 1130 × 1133), established lordship in northern England in 1090s * [[Bernard I de Balliol]] (died 1154 x 1162), nephew of Guy * [[Guy II de Balliol]] (died early 1160s x 1167), son of Bernard * [[Bernard II de Balliol]] (died c. 1190), brother of above * [[Eustace de Balliol]] (died c. 1209), cousin of above * [[Hugh de Balliol]] (died 1229), son of above * [[John I de Balliol]] (died 1268), son of above, the founder of [[Balliol College]] * [[John II de Balliol]] (died 1314), son of above, ruled from 1292 to 1296, and claimed the throne as great-great-great-grandson of [[David I of Scotland]] of the [[House of Dunkeld]]. * [[Edward Balliol|Edward de Balliol]] (died 1364), eldest son of John, who from 1332 to about 1338 was a pretender to the Scottish throne in opposition to [[David II of Scotland]] with support of the English. Both Balliols had English support for their claims; both were deposed. Edward died without issue, but the Balliol descent continued through his cousin Christine de Lindsay (granddaughter of John II), who married [[Enguerrand V, Lord of Coucy]], to the lords of [[Château de Coucy|Coucy]] and ultimately the [[House of Bourbon|Bourbon]] kings of France and Spain. ==See also== *[[List of British monarchs]] *[[Scottish monarchs family tree]] ==References== {{Wikisource1911Enc|Baliol}} * Stell, G. P., "Balliol, Bernard de (d. 1154x62)", ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/1204 , accessed 24 Jan 2008] * Stell, G. P., "Balliol, Bernard de (d. c.1190)", ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/1204 , accessed 24 Jan 2008] * Stell, G. P., "Balliol , John de (b. before 1208, d. 1268)", ''Oxford Dictionary of National Biography'', Oxford University Press, 2004 [http://www.oxforddnb.com/view/article/1208 , accessed 24 Jan 2008] {{s-start}} {{s-hou|House of Balliol|||||name=*[[Royal House]]*}} {{s-bef|before=[[House of Dunkeld]]}} {{s-ttl|title=[[Dynasty|Ruling House]] of the [[Kingdom of Scotland]]|years=1292 – 1296
''Pretender 1332 – 1338''}} {{s-aft|after=[[House of Bruce]]}} {{s-end}} {{Royal houses of Europe}} {{Normandy-stub}} [[Category:House of Balliol| ]] [[Category:People from Picardy]] [[Category:Scottish royal houses|Balliol]] [[Category:Anglo-Norman families|Balliol]] [[Category:Scoto-Normans]]

'''(Select areas)''' | cable serv 2 = [[iO Digital Cable Service|Cablevision]] ([[United States|USA]]) | cable chan 2 = Channel 1118
([[New York City|NY]], [[New Jersey|NJ]] & [[Connecticut|CT]]) | cable serv 3 = [[Verizon FiOS]] ([[United States|USA]]) | cable chan 3 = Channel 1782 | iptv serv 1 = [[Free (ISP)|Free]] ([[France]]) | iptv chan 1 = Channel 614 | iptv serv 2 = [[SFR]] ([[France]]) | iptv chan 2 = Channel 612 |}} The '''Israeli Network''' ({{lang-he|'''הערוץ הישראלי'''}}) is an international private [[television]] network. It launched September 2001 and features programming from all the top networks in Israel including [[Kan 11]], [[Keshet 12]], [[Reshet 13]], [[Channel 10 (Israel)|Channel 10]], Channel 8, [[Israeli Educational Television]], [[Arutz HaYeladim]], [[Hop!]] and [[Sport 5|Sports Channel]]. The Israeli Network is available in [[North America]]; in the [[United States]] via [[Dish Network]], [[Cablevision]], [[Verizon FiOS]] & [[Comcast]] and in Canada via [[Rogers Cable]] & [[Bell Fibe TV]] through a partnership with Ethnic Channels Group. It is also available in Europe and Africa through select providers and now in Caribbean Latin America Middle East Asia and the Pacific. {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2016}} {{Use British English|date=June 2016}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Jokers Wild | image = | caption = | alt = | landscape = | background = group_or_band | genre = [[Rock music|Rock]] | origin = Cambridge, England | years_active = | label = | website = | current_members = | past_members = *David Altham *[[David Gilmour]] *Peter Gilmour *John Gordon *[[Dick Parry]] *Tony Sainty *Clive Welham *[[Rick Wills]] *[[Willie Wilson (drummer)|Willie Wilson]] }} <!--NOTE: UK bands by convention of British English here are described as WERE. Do not use WAS!--> '''Jokers Wild''' were an English [[Rock music|Rock]] band formed in Cambridge in 1964.<ref name="Mabbett-3">{{Cite book| publisher = Omnibus | isbn = 9781849383707 | last = Mabbett | first = Andy | title = Pink Floyd - The Music and the Mystery | location = London | year = 2010 }}</ref><ref name="atagong.com">[http://atagong.com/iggy/archives/2012/05/rip-clive-welham-a-biscuit-tin-with-knives.html]</ref> The line-up included guitarist [[David Gilmour]] and saxophonist [[Dick Parry]]. Gilmour went on to join the band [[Pink Floyd]] and Parry went on to become a session musician, playing on three Pink Floyd studio albums and one live album.<ref name="Mabbett-3" /> Parry also went on to join [[On an Island Tour|Gilmour's 2006 solo tour]].
==Recording sessions== Their only releases were a privately pressed, single-sided [[studio album]] (carrying catalogue number RSLP 007) and [[single (music)|single]] (RSR 0031), of which only forty or fifty copies each were made. These were recorded at Regent Sound studio in Denmark Street, London.<ref name="Mabbett-3" /><ref name=toby11>{{cite book|last=Manning|first=Toby|title=The Rough Guide to Pink Floyd|year=2006|publisher=Rough Guides|location=London|isbn=1-84353-575-0|edition=1st|page=10|chapter=The Early Years}}</ref> A tape recording of the LP is held by the [[British Library]]'s [[British Library Sound Archive]].<ref name="Mabbett-3" /><ref>Reference C-625/1, [http://cadensa.bl.uk/uhtbin/cgisirsi/4FR9hTOPPT/WORKS-FILE/293930044/8/114866/Jokers+Wild Cadensa.bl.uk]</ref>
Together with record producer [[Jonathan King]], they recorded what was to have been a UK cover version of [[Sam & Dave]]'s "[[Hold On, I'm Comin' (song)|Hold On, I'm Comin']]", but the original was released in the UK, so Jokers Wild's version was not released.<ref name=toby11/>
==Members== *David Altham – guitar, vocals, keyboards *[[David Gilmour]] – vocals, guitar, harmonica *Peter Gilmour – bass guitar, vocals (David Gilmour's brother) *John Gordon – guitar, vocals *[[Dick Parry]] – saxophone, trumpet *Tony Sainty – bass guitar, percussion, vocals (left in 1966; born 1943) *Clive Welham – drum, vocals (to mid-1965; born 1944 died 9 May 2012<ref name="atagong.com"/>) *[[Rick Wills]] – bass guitar (replacing Tony Sainty) *[[Willie Wilson (drummer)|Willie Wilson]] – drums (mid-1965 onwards)
Wills later played with, Peter Frampton, [[Foreigner (band)|Foreigner]] and [[Bad Company]]. Both he and Wilson played on David Gilmour's [[David Gilmour (album)|eponymous first solo album]]; Parry played on four Pink Floyd records, ''Dark Side of the Moon'', ''Wish You Were Here'', ''Division Bell'' and the live double album ''Pulse'' and had a career as a [[session musician]].
Wilson later played drums and bass on [[Syd Barrett]]'s solo albums, ''[[The Madcap Laughs]]'' and ''Barrett'',<ref name=toby71>{{cite book|last=Manning|first=Toby|title=The Rough Guide to Pink Floyd|year=2006|publisher=Rough Guides|location=London|isbn=1-84353-575-0|page=71|edition=1st|chapter=Set the Controls}}</ref> the later sessions of which were produced by Gilmour.<ref name=MCLM8>{{cite book|last=Jones|first=Malcolm|title=The Making of The Madcap Laughs|year=2003|publisher=Brain Damage|edition=21st Anniversary|accessdate=13 August 2012|page=8}}</ref> He also was a surrogate drummer on the live shows and soundtrack for ''[[Is There Anybody Out There? The Wall Live 1980–81]]'' which came out in 2000. Between 1973 and 1978 he was a member of [[Quiver (band)|Quiver]].
==Track list== The album's five tracks, featuring David Gilmour and Dave Altham on vocals, were:<ref name="Mabbett-3" />
# "[[Why Do Fools Fall in Love (song)|Why Do Fools Fall in Love]]" # "[[Walk Like a Man (The Four Seasons song)|Walk Like a Man]]" # "Don't Ask Me (What I Say)" # "[[Big Girls Don't Cry (The Four Seasons song)|Big Girls Don't Cry]]" # "Beautiful Delilah"
The single had "Don't Ask Me (What I Say)", backed by "Why Do Fools Fall in Love".<ref name="Mabbett-3" />
==References== {{Reflist}}
