revision.text:
{{BLP sources|date=July 2018}} {{pp-blp|small=yes}} {{Use mdy dates|date=June 2012}} {{DISPLAYTITLE:List of ''The Howard Stern Show'' staff}} {{Original research|date=February 2016}} Throughout its run spanning four decades and multiple media, ''[[The Howard Stern Show]]'' has been home to a number of staff members and contributors.
==Current staff== These staffers currently work for and appear on the show on a regular, if not hourly basis. ===In-studio=== These people currently sit in the studio throughout the entire broadcast. ====Howard Stern==== {{Main|Howard Stern}} Howard Stern is the host of the show, which essentially is a discussion of topics that include world affairs, celebrity gossip, [[self-deprecation]], bodily functions, conflicts among his staff, his own personal family matters, and the antics of the show's [[Wack Pack]].<ref name="PrivateParts">{{cite book|last=Stern |first=Howard|title=Private Parts|year=1993|publisher=Simon and Schuster|isbn=0-671-50100-3|page=688|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LTJFsGNJwyYC&printsec=frontcover}}</ref> Self-proclaimed "King of All Media".
====Robin Quivers==== {{Main|Robin Quivers}} Robin Ophelia Quivers is a native of Baltimore, Maryland, and first met Stern after being assigned as his newswoman at [[WWDC]] in March 1981. She has been his co-host and news reader ever since. She is a former nurse and Captain in the United States Air Force. Quivers briefly left the show towards the end of her time at WWDC when Stern made a deal at [[WNBC (AM)|WNBC]] in 1982, and did not realize WNBC initially refused to hire her. Quivers returned to the show at WNBC a month after Stern.<ref name="QuiversOfLife">{{cite book|last=Quivers|first=Robin|title=Quivers, A Life|year=1995|publisher=Harper Collins|isbn=0-06-039153-7|page=341 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=3Fj1h-gIbUsC}}</ref>
Stern once said that Quivers is the only person on the show that he allowed to talk freely during the broadcast, although comedian [[Artie Lange]] was allowed this privilege as well during his years on the show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/news07/12-17.htm#wed|title=The History Of Howard Stern Day 3 – Howard Meets Robin In Washington DC. |date=December 19, 2007}}</ref>
====Fred Norris==== {{Main|Fred Norris}} Of the show's staff, Stern met Norris first, in 1979, when the two worked as disc jockeys at [[WCCC (FM)|WCCC]] in [[Hartford, Connecticut]]. Norris worked the overnight slot, after which Stern hosted the morning slot.<ref>{{cite book |last=Stern|first=Howard |authorlink=Howard Stern |author2=Larry "Ratso" Sloman|editor=[[Judith Regan]]|title=[[Private Parts (book)|Private Parts]] |edition=1st|publisher=[[Simon & Schuster]]|isbn=978-0-671-88016-3 |oclc=28968496|page=127|chapter=Mein Kampf "My Struggle"|quote=But there was one good thing about Hartford. I met Fred "Earth Dog" Norris there. Fred was going to college and he was the overnight guy. He was a funny guy and a good writer and he had a knack for doing impressions.}}</ref> Although Stern left shortly afterwards, Norris stayed at WCCC until joining Stern and Quivers at Washington, D.C.'s [[WWDC]] in 1981.<ref name="PrivateParts" /> The "Earth Dog Fred" nickname originated in Washington, as Norris replaced an engineer nicknamed "Earth Dog Brent."<ref>{{cite book|author=Luigi Lucaire|title=Howard Stern A To Z|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=y6H9C0Z6EYEC&pg=PT37|accessdate=5 June 2012|date=15 January 1997|publisher=Macmillan|isbn=978-0-312-15144-7|page=37}}</ref>
Norris is married to Allison (née Furman) and they have one daughter, Tess.
Norris' current role on the show is to provide [[sound effects]], organize and direct commercials and live reads, and occasionally perform writing duties. Norris also provides impersonations of show regulars, celebrities and others.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/whoswho/fre.htm |title=Who's Who |publisher=MarksFriggin.com |accessdate=2015-05-20}}</ref><ref name="ShowBios2">{{cite web|url=http://www.howardstern.com/bio.hs |title=Stern Show Bios |publisher=Howardstern.com |accessdate=June 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120527220953/http://www.howardstern.com/bio.hs |archivedate=May 27, 2012}}</ref>
====George Takei==== {{Main|George Takei}} [[File:George Takei.jpg|thumb|George Takei]]
George Takei occasionally serves as the show's announcer.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/news10/12-6.htm#tue|title=Monday, January 9, 2006}}</ref> Before joining the show, Takei became popular among the cast after [[soundbites]] of his audiobook about his career on ''[[Star Trek: The Original Series|Star Trek]]'' were played on the show. The clips stood out due to his deep [[baritone]] voice and pitch perfect enunciation, and, thus, were frequently played on the show. In 2006, when the show moved to [[Sirius XM Holdings|Sirius]], Stern announced that Takei was the show's official announcer.
===Outside the studio=== These are the behind-the-scenes personnel, although in the Stern world, many of these staff members appear on air.
====Steve Brandano==== Brandano, previously known as "Steve The Intern," answers Stern's phones, is a contributor on ''[[The Wrap-Up Show]]'', and was formerly the host of the Thursday night intern show.
====Benjy Bronk==== Benjy Bronk (born Sept. 4, 1967)<ref>http://www.tmz.com/person/benjy-bronk/</ref> began working on ''The Howard Stern Show'' as an intern in 1998. Bronk eventually earned a paid position conducting pre-interviews of show guests and gathering articles for [[Robin Quivers]]' news. In 2000, Benjy was given an in-studio seat next to writers [[Jackie Martling]] and [[Fred Norris]], writing on-the-spot jokes for Stern as the show transpired.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.heebmagazine.com/blog/view/598 |title=Heeb HQ Benjy Bronk: The Heeb Interview |author=dreidel_hustler |publisher=Heeb Media, LLC |date=March 19, 2008 |accessdate=January 19, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081120051813/http://www.heebmagazine.com/blog/view/598 |archivedate=November 20, 2008}}</ref>
After Martling left the show in early 2001, Bronk continued as an in-studio joke writer with Norris. When the [[Howard Stern Show]] moved to Sirius satellite radio in January 2006, Bronk continued in his role as an in-studio joke writer. In October 2016, he was banished from the studio indefinitely after arriving late for work, the last in a long history of tardiness.
====Richard Christy==== {{Main|Richard Christy}} While working as an electrician in Florida and playing as a drummer in a number of [[heavy metal music|heavy metal]] bands including [[Iced Earth]] and [[Death (metal band)|Death]], Christy began calling into the show from October 1999, initially sending voice mails to the show's assistant producer [[K. C. Armstrong]], which were played on-air. From 2001 to 2003, Christy sent song parodies and bits about Armstrong and show co-host [[The Howard Stern Show staff#Robin Quivers|Robin Quivers]] including some like "It's K.C.'s Sausage Party" (a parody of "[[It's My Party (Lesley Gore song)|It's My Party]]")<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/all_comments?v=gKc6NAK3G0M |title=Broadcast Yourself |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=June 5, 2012}}</ref> and "Gay Photograph" (a parody of the [[Def Leppard]] song "Photograph")<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nH3e-GzdEX4 |title=KC posed for gay photographs. |publisher=YouTube |accessdate=June 5, 2012}}</ref> that continue to be played on the show to this day. Christy made his first visit to the show on April 24, 2003, where he played a round of blackjack to win a date with a porn star.
In July 2004, when the show was holding a "Win John's Job" contest following the departure of [[Stuttering John]] from the show, Christy won the position as voted by fans. Since joining the show, Christy has become known for his prank calls, song parodies, unique personality, and "show stunts" he's performed with his writing partner [[Sal the Stockbroker]].<ref name="WinJohn">{{cite web|url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/news04/6-28.htm#thu|title=''Get John's Job'' Elimination Round. |date=July 1, 2004}}</ref>
Christy is currently the drummer in the heavy-metal band [[Charred Walls of the Damned]].
====Gary Dell'Abate==== {{Main|Gary Dell'Abate}} Gary Dell'Abate, aka '''Baba Booey''', serves as the show's head producer. Hired right after graduating from [[Adelphi University]] in 1984 and briefly anglicizing his name to Gary Dell, he has worked for the show ever since. Dell'Abate is mocked on the Stern Show for his appearance, gullibility (he once booked a mentally challenged woman who claimed to be [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]]'s sister), and frequent mispronunciations (for example, insisting that actor [[Nick Nolte]]'s last name was pronounced "Nolt"). He earned the nickname "Baba Booey" after insisting it to be the correct name of the cartoon character [[Baba Looey]].<ref name="BabaBooey">{{cite book|last=Dell'Abate|first=Gary|title=They Call Me Baba Booey|year=2010|publisher=Spiegel & Grau|isbn=1-4000-6955-6|page=304}}</ref>
====Sal Governale==== Salvatore "Sal" Governale, sometimes referred to as '''Sal the Stockbroker''', was originally a frequent caller who worked as a stockbroker. Stern took notice after numerous calls mocking Gary Dell'Abate. Although he came in second in the "Win John's Job" contest to his future writing partner, [[Richard Christy]], Sal was eventually hired as a prank caller/writer for the show, and is now credited as a producer.
====J. D. Harmeyer==== Born in December 1979 in [[Fairborn, Ohio]], Jamie Daniel "J. D." Harmeyer is Stern's head media producer. He records television shows, pulls clips from the internet and edits together highlights from recent happenings in movies and TV. He attended [[Full Sail University]] in [[Winter Park, Florida]].<ref>https://oceanviewpress.wordpress.com/2013/10/17/j-d-harmeyer-from-the-howard-stern-show/</ref>
====Jon Hein==== {{Main|Jon Hein}} [[File:Jon Hein by Gage Skidmore.jpg|thumb|Jon Hein]]
Jon Hein made his first guest appearances on the show on May 3, 2001,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/news01/4-30-01.htm |title=Jon Hein From JumpTheShark.com Comes In. |date=May 3, 2001|publisher=MarksFriggin |accessdate=November 18, 2009}}</ref> discussing television shows that have "[[jumped the shark]]", a term he uses to describe when a show has passed its prime (based on an episode of the show, ''[[Happy Days]]'', where a previously popular and well-done show clearly and memorably began to go downhill). In late 2005, while experimental programming was broadcast on [[Howard 100 and Howard 101]], Hein presented the first edition of ''Superfan Roundtable''. His success in on-air hosting led him to become the co-host of ''[[The Wrap-Up Show]]'' when the show moved to [[Sirius XM]] in January 2006.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/news05/11-14.htm |title=More Letterman Discussions |date=November 18, 2005 |publisher=MarksFriggin |accessdate=November 18, 2009}}</ref>
Hein is also a cohost on the weekly Thursday show, "Jon Hein's TV Show" with [[J. D. Harmeyer]], [[Steve Brandano]], and Jenny Hutt, as well as the weekly Friday show "Geek Time" with Jason Kaplan and Ralph Cirella. The show has since been cancelled.
====Jason Kaplan==== Jason Kaplan is a senior producer for the show. He has many duties, including writing the daily show rundown that appears on the show's website, and taking photos that appear alongside the daily rundown. In September 2007, Jason and [[HowardTV]] director Scott DePace engaged in an intense feud stemming from their political differences.
Jason was married to his girlfriend, Janis on November 8, 2008. Notable guests at the ceremony included Howard Stern, Robin Quivers, Gary Dell'Abate, as well as the majority of Stern's staff. The reception featured speeches from fellow staff members, Ronnie Mund and J. D. Harmeyer. Kaplan hosts "Page 69" along with Will Murray. On the wrap-up show on August 19, Kaplan stated that he grew up in Stanhope, NJ and attended [[Rutgers University]].
Kaplan hosted a monthly show called ''The Fat Guy Show,''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.siriusxm.com/servlet/Satellite?c=SXM_Channel_C&childpagename=SXM/SXM_Channel_C/ChannelProgramList&cid=1282009842244&pagename=SXM/Wrapper&packedargs=tzone%3DPacific |title=Hear the Revolution – Howard Stern – Entertainment – Howard 101 – SiriusXM Satellite Radio – SiriusXM Radio |publisher=Siriusxm.com |accessdate=June 5, 2012}}</ref> Kaplan is also a producer of the monthly show ''Geek Time'' that airs on every Friday with Jon Hein and Ralph Cirella.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/whoswho/jason.htm|title=Who's Who: Jason Kaplan}}</ref>
====Ronnie Mund==== '''Ronald Mund''', commonly referred to as '''Ronnie the Limo Driver''', is Stern's [[limousine]] driver and bodyguard, and the head of security for the Stern show complex at Sirius Radio.<ref>{{cite news|title=Notebook – McGehee has proof of childhood Indy dreams |publisher=CNN/Sports Illustrated |date=May 22, 2001 |url=http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/motorsports/2001/indy500/news/2001/05/19/notebook_mcgehee/ |accessdate=January 16, 2007 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080526035326/http://sportsillustrated.cnn.com/motorsports/2001/indy500/news/2001/05/19/notebook_mcgehee/ |archivedate=May 26, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Buy Stern's ride |publisher=CNNMoney.com |date=May 19, 2005 |url=http://money.cnn.com/2005/05/19/news/newsmakers/stern_limo/ |accessdate=January 16, 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |last=Popkin |first=Helen |title=Howard Stern's cast of characters, from Robin to High Pitch Eric |publisher=MSNBC |date=December 14, 2005 |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/9853210/ |accessdate=January 16, 2007}}</ref> After a career in the Air Force, Mund started a limo business. He started driving for Stern in 1986, and quickly became a character on the radio show. In 2011, Ronnie began touring the US with other talent from ''The Howard Stern Show'' on the Ronnie Mund Block Party.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sternfannetwork.com/xen/index.php?threads/the-ronnie-mund-block-party-tour.654811/ |publisher=Stern Fan Network |title=Ronnie Mund Block Party Tour |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120726114907/http://www.sternfannetwork.com/xen/index.php?threads%2Fthe-ronnie-mund-block-party-tour.654811%2F |archivedate=July 26, 2012 |df=mdy}}</ref> In March 2013, Ronnie hosted a 4-day event in Jamaica called the Ronnie Mund Jamaican Getaway.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://ronniemundjamaicangetaway.com/ |publisher=CleanBox Entertainment |title=Ronnie Mund Jamaican Getaway |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120814154550/http://ronniemundjamaicangetaway.com/ |archivedate=August 14, 2012 |df=mdy}}</ref>
====Will Murray==== '''Will Murray''' is the show's researcher and segment producer. He preinterviews all guests, and compiles pages of notes of research for Howard to use during interviews. He and fellow producer Jason Kaplan host the [[Howard 100 News]] segment "Page 69."
On September 5, 2008, Will married his long-time girlfriend. A [[Philadelphia]] area native, he is a huge Philadelphia sports fan, and is a graduate of [[Syracuse University]].
====Scott Salem==== '''Scott the Engineer''' is the show's long-time engineer, having joined on February 10, 1986.<ref name='act2guide1'>{{cite web |url = http://www.sirius.com/wo/i/howard/history_II/part_a/hoh-120908_a.swf |title = The History of Howard Stern Act II Interactive Guide – Week 1|publisher = Sirius.com }}{{dead link|date=September 2015}}</ref> Having previously worked at [[WABC (AM)]] and [[WPLJ]] in New York City, Salem received a [[voice mail]] from [[Jimmy Fink]], then the morning personality at [[WNYL (FM)|WXRK]] informing him of his new position.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.marksfriggin.com/news08/12-22.htm#mon |title = THoHS:A2 – Howard's Move To Mornings, Scott Salem. December 22, 2008. 10:10 am |publisher = MarksFriggin |accessdate=November 18, 2009 }}</ref>
In 1996, the ''[[Austin American-Statesman]]'' wrote that Scott is "always threatening to quit or on the verge of being fired, he's the show's whipping boy for technical problems".<ref>{{cite news |last=Corcoran |first=Michael |title=Stern's cast of irregulars |publisher=Austin American-Statesman (TX) |date=April 4, 1996| page = 65}}</ref> In 2007, Salem made a onetime appearance on tour with the Killers of Comedy, performing stand-up followed by a Q&A session with the audience. Salem is an avid bowler and has competed in and appeared at several [[Professional Bowlers Association|PBA]] tour events.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pba.com/LiveScoring/Qual_Ind_Results.aspx?ContactId=40276&tournamentId=1656 |title=Brunswick Pro Bowling Cheetah Championship Scott Salem |publisher=PBA.com |date=January 17, 2011 |accessdate=June 5, 2012}}</ref>
'''Ron Tarrant'''
[[Ron Tarrant]] joined the Howard Stern Channels in 2016 from Canada as the Head Imaging/Sound Designer & new voice of the Howard Stern Show/Channels.
====Mike Trainor==== {{Main|Mike Trainor}} Mike Trainor joined the show in 2014 as writer and producer.
====Marci Turk==== '''Marci Turk''' is [[chief operating officer]] of Stern's channels. A former employee of author [[David Allen (author)|David Allen]], she is a prominent advocator of his ''[[Getting Things Done]]'' method of [[time management]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Meet The Howard Stern Show staff: Marci Turk |url=http://www.howardstern.com/profiles/marci-turk |website=HowardStern.com |accessdate=23 September 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130802123153/http://www.howardstern.com/profiles/marci-turk |archivedate=August 2, 2013 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Marci Turk|url=http://pmiovoc.org/index.php?option%3Dcom_docman%26task%3Ddoc_download%26gid%3D159%26Itemid%3D58&usg=AFQjCNE_EqbSUkNlXijSfbRzH4Bb0Wyh8A&sig2=Vu3nf8-h9n_WNiMYX_7Tgg|website=PMI|accessdate=23 September 2015}}</ref>
===Howard 100 News=== {{Main|Howard 100 News}} The Howard 100 News team reports on events that relate to the Howard Stern Universe.
====Shuli Egar==== '''Shuli Egar''' is a comedian who first appeared on the show in June 2003. When Stern announced his planned move to Sirius and created [[Howard 100 News]] in 2005, Egar was an early hire. He was quickly promoted to [[The Wack Pack]] beat and also filled in for Lisa G and Steve Langford when they were out.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/news03/6-2.htm|title=Comedian Shuli Egar Sits In For The News And The Gossip Game |date=June 6, 2003}}</ref> As of 2016, he is the only original member of the Howard 100 News team that remains on staff.
====Jon Leiberman==== {{Main|Jon Leiberman}} '''Jon Leiberman''' is an in-studio and remote correspondent for Howard 100 News who was hired in July 2011.
==="The Tapes" Team=== '''The Tapes Team''' produces specials out of the archives of the Howard Stern Show, such as "Howard Stern: The Peacock Years", "The Gayest Week Ever", "The History of Howard Stern", as well as the daily and weekend editions of Sternthology. Members of this team do not appear on the air.
* Jeremy Lipkin: Director of Creative Channel Development * Rich Gibbons: Senior Producer * Paul Grassini: Senior Producer * David LeClaire: Senior Producer * Ben Barto: Coordinating Producer * Brent Hatley: Senior Producer * Al Ragone: Producer * Ryan Rasmason: Producer * Ryan Pienciak: News Director * Sean Hanahue: Producer * Rahsaan Rogers: Associate Producer * Mark Nowak: Associate Producer * Mike Fox: Associate Producer * Greg Giordano: Production Assistant
===Hosts of ''Howard 101'' shows=== ====Greg Fitzsimmons==== {{Main|Greg Fitzsimmons}} '''Greg Fitzsimmons''' is the host of ''[[The Greg Fitzsimmons Show]]'' on [[Howard 100 and Howard 101|Howard 101]].
==Former staff and associates== The following people all saw significant air-time when they worked with Stern. Some were either show staffers who went on to bigger and better things, interns, Stern's bosses, and station support staff who for a time were all integral to the show.
===Former radio staff=== ====K. C. Armstrong==== [[File:KCArmstrongPhiladelphia.jpg|thumb|K. C. Armstrong]]
'''Kyle Casey "K. C." Armstrong''' (born July 17, 1975), who grew up in nearby [[Suffolk County, New York]], began working on the show as an intern in 1997 and later became [[Radio producer|associate producer]] from 1998 to 2004.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/news96_97/may-97.htm |title=K.C. Interviews Marv Albert. |date=May 23, 1997 |publisher=MarksFriggin.com |accessdate=December 4, 2009 }}</ref><ref name=KCDB>{{cite web |url=http://www3.sympatico.ca/brooksdr/kc/main.htm |title=The KC Information Database |accessdate=July 6, 2007 |last=Brooks |first=David |date=February 3, 2005 }}</ref> In a 2005 interview, Armstrong revealed that he had been fired from the show by WXRK general manager [[Tom Chiusano]] for lapsing back into drug use after spending time in rehab.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.yesbutnobutyes.com/archives/2005/06/kc_armstrong_in_3.html|title=KC Armstrong Interview - The Final Chapter |date=June 29, 2005 |publisher=YesButNoButYes |accessdate=June 13, 2012}}</ref>
Armstrong eventually moved to [[California]], where he tried to start a career in acting. He released a comedy DVD called ''Die Laughing''. He has acted in three movies – ''Death4Told'', ''Grace and the Storm'' and ''Secret War'' and appears on the comedy DVD series ''Meet the Creeps''.
====Lee Davis==== '''"Boy" Lee Davis''' was the original Stern show producer at WNBC before Gary Dell'Abate. He left to become the producer of the [[Soupy Sales]] show.<ref name="Peacock2">{{cite web|url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/news10/10-4.htm#tue|title=Tuesday, October 5, 2010}}</ref>
====Steve Freid==== '''Steve "the Engineer" Freid''' first worked with Ben Stern and later worked with Howard when he arrived at K-Rock. He gained notoriety performing as the character '''Wood Yi''', a parody of actor/director [[Woody Allen]]. Billy West came up with the idea for the character in the early 1990s, and Steve was chosen to play the part due to having a similar-sounding voice. When performing as Wood Yi, Steve read lines supplied to him by the shows' staff, reciting them in a [[deadpan]] manner.
====Gary Garver==== '''Gary Garver''' was a West Coast-based correspondent for ''[[The Howard Stern Show]]'' who first started working for the show in 1991 when he was an operator at [[KAMP-FM|KLSX]], the show's [[Los Angeles]] affiliate. He was sent to awards shows, movie premieres and television conventions to ask [[John Melendez|"Stuttering John"]]-type questions to celebrities and [[Minor celebrity#15 minutes of fame|has-beens]].
====Steve Grillo==== Former Stern Show intern and associate producer at [[WNYL (FM)|WXRK]], known as "Gorilla". Howard dedicated his second book ''[[Miss America (book)|Miss America]]'' to Steve. Grillo conducted movie reviews for [[Howard 100 News]] in 2006. As homage to his former duties as a Stern show intern, he rated films by awarding them a certain number of potatoes.
====Artie Lange==== [[File:Artielangesit.jpg|thumb|Artie Lange]] {{Main|Artie Lange}}
Lange's first appearance on the show was as a guest alongside fellow comedian [[Norm Macdonald]] on January 8, 1998, following a bit involving [[Scott Salem|Scott the Engineer]] and his challenge to perform 17 complete [[push-up]]s. Although appearing with Macdonald to promote the film ''[[Dirty Work (1998 film)|Dirty Work]]'', Lange had been a fan of Stern since the 1980s when he used to listen with his father. In fact, after Lange's father was paralyzed in 1987, show producer [[Gary Dell'Abate]] sent Lange an autographed jacket which Lange auctioned off for $2,000 to help support his family.
Following the departure of the show's writer and comedian [[Jackie Martling|Jackie "The Jokeman" Martling]] in 2001, several comedians "auditioned" for Martling's seat by sitting in for a couple of shows. Lange's first appearance in what became known as "The Jackie Chair" occurred for 2 days, on May 7 and 8, 2001. The temporary appearance consisted of being Stern's sidekick along with Quivers, and Lange frequently told personal stories, usually regarding alcohol, drugs, food and prostitutes. On October 29, 2001, Lange joined the show full-time and was voted favorite by Howard's fans in 2009.
Lange left the show in December 2009. At first the leave was thought to be temporary, but in early 2010 he attempted suicide at his apartment in [[Hoboken, New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/news/2010/01/07/2010-01-07_artie_lange.html |location=New York |work=Daily News |title=Artie Lange used 13-inch kitchen knife in violent suicide try; released from hospital after surgery |first=Cristina |last=Everett |date=January 8, 2010}}</ref> The incident has not been discussed in great detail on the show and for much of 2010, Stern mentioned that Lange would return when he was healthy. However, in 2011 the show and the Howard 100 News began to reference Lange as a "former" staffer. On October 3, 2011, Lange began co-hosting ''[[The Artie Lange Show|The Nick & Artie Show]]'' with comedian Nick DiPaolo. This show aired on Directv. In April 2014, Artie was informed before the show that Directv had cancelled his show. He went on air that night for the last time as a part of the Directv team. He currently is the host of a podcast called "The Artie Lange Uncensored Podcast."
====John Melendez==== {{Main|John Melendez}} In 1988, '''Stuttering John''' was attending [[New York University]]'s film school, and belonged to a band called "Rock Slide". His college roommate, [[Mitch Fatel]], was on the verge of quitting his internship with ''[[The Howard Stern Show]]'', when Melendez begged him for a recommendation for an internship on the show. Producer [[Gary Dell'Abate]] interviewed Melendez and mentioned his stuttering problem to [[Howard Stern|Stern]], who decided to hire him as a field reporter.
On Stern's show, Melendez conducted outrageous street interviews and appeared at press conferences, asking off-the-wall questions to various celebrities, including [[Gennifer Flowers]], [[Ringo Starr]], [[Burt Reynolds]], [[Tommy Lasorda]], [[Larry King]] and the [[Dalai Lama]]. He also provided comic relief on the show itself with his misadventures, poor grammar, and sloppy pronunciation. Melendez left the show after being offered a half-million dollar contract as the announcer for ''[[The Tonight Show]]'' with [[Jay Leno]].
====Al Rosenberg==== '''Al Rosenberg''' was a writer/performer for Howard on [[WNBC (AM)|WNBC]].{{when|date=March 2012}} He did numerous voice impressions including [[Sue Simmons]] and [[Ruth Westheimer|Dr. Ruth Westheimer]]. In ''[[The History of Howard Stern]]'', Howard stated that he hired Al after Imus fired him so that he (Imus) could hire his girlfriend to replace Rosenberg. He stayed on at WNBC after Howard was fired because he was still under contract to the station. Al also worked on [[WBBR|WNEW-AM]] radio as one half of the morning team with Bob Fitzsimmons. He also worked with [[Ted Brown (radio)|Ted Brown]]. He later worked again for Howard on the [[WWOR-TV|"Channel 9 Show"]] as a writer.{{when|date=March 2012}} Al called into Stern's show in 2007 (during a [[Paul Mooney (comedian)|Paul Mooney]] interview) to discuss Imus' racism.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.howardstern.com/rundown.hs?d=1176868800 |title=Rundown, April 18, 2007 |publisher=Howardstern.com |date=April 18, 2007 |accessdate=June 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120217021951/http://www.howardstern.com/rundown.hs?d=1176868800 |archivedate=February 17, 2012}}</ref> He also appeared on [[Howard 101]]'s defunct "Miserable Men" program.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/news07/12-17.htm#thu|title=MarksFriggin archives, Monday, December 17, 2007}}</ref>
He currently works doing speaking engagements and voice-over work.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.alrosenberg.com/Home_Page.html |title=Home of Al Rosenberg |publisher=Alrosenberg.com |accessdate=June 5, 2012}}</ref> He also serves on the board of Rise, a non-profit organization and currently serves as Deputy Mayor for [[East Windsor Township, New Jersey]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nj.com/mercer/index.ssf/2013/09/republicans_challenge_incumbent_democrats_in_east_windsor_council_election.html#incart_river |title=Republicans challenge incumbent Democrats for council seats in East Windsor |date=September 14, 2013 |accessdate=September 14, 2013 |author=Nicole Mulvaney |newspaper=[[The Times of Trenton]]}}</ref>
====Billy West==== {{Main|Billy West}} [[File:Billy West by Gage Skidmore 3.jpg|thumb|200px|Billy West]] Billy West provided the show with comedy impersonations, part-time, beginning on November 7, 1988.<ref name='act2guide2'>{{cite web|url=http://www.sirius.com/wo/i/howard/history_II/part_b/hoh-120908_b.swf|title=The History of Howard Stern Act II Interactive Guide – Week 2|publisher=Sirius.com}} {{dead link|date=September 2015}}</ref> He was known for his impressions of [[Marge Schott]] and show comedian [[Jackie Martling]]. West's final appearance was on November 1, 1995, before he left the show over contract and salary disputes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.koam.com/haven/west2.html|title=Stern Shocked As West Walks!|publisher=King of All Media Interactive Newsletter|accessdate=December 4, 2009}}</ref><ref>[http://www.ugo.com/channels/dvd/features/billywest/default.asp Interview with UGO.com (20th question)] Accessed January 29, 2007. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20071013191554/http://www.ugo.com/channels/dvd/features/billywest/default.asp |date=October 13, 2007}}</ref> On February 19 and 20, 2007, a special two-part retrospective of West's work on the show was broadcast on [[Howard 100 and Howard 101]], covering over 11 hours.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/news07/2-19.htm|title=For the week of February 19, 2007 to February 23, 2007|publisher=MarksFriggin.com|accessdate=December 4, 2009}}</ref>
West was an occasional contributor to ''[[The Adam Carolla Show (terrestrial radio)|The Adam Carolla Show]]'', a syndicated morning radio show that replaced Stern in cities along the West Coast.{{cn|date=December 2016}}
===Former radio associates=== ====Bubba Clem==== {{Main|Bubba the Love Sponge}} ''Bubba the Love Sponge'' is both the title of, and name of the host of, a radio show airing on Howard 101 from 2005 to the end of 2010. Bubba (actual legal name Bubba The Love Sponge Clem, born Todd Clem) had previously been "exiled" from radio after a great deal of controversy over his terrestrial radio show, based in Tampa, Florida. Stern brought Bubba's show aboard and in so doing relaunched Bubba's career and show. Bubba credits Stern for reviving his career.
The show left Sirius XM at the end of 2010<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.tampabay.com/blogs/media/content/tampa-shock-jock-bubba-love-sponge-leaves-sirius-xm-internet-radio |title=Tampa shock jock Bubba the Love Sponge leaves Sirius XM for Internet radio |work=Tampa Bay Times |date=January 4, 2011 |accessdate=June 5, 2012}}</ref> and moved to [[RadioIO]] Internet Radio and syndicated terrestrial radio.
====Donna Fiducia==== {{Main|Donna Fiducia}} '''Donna Fiducia''' was an on-air reporter on WNBC radio during Stern's tenure there. They had frequent by-play while she was on the air.
====Rev. Bob Levy==== {{Main|Reverend Bob Levy}} '''"Reverend" Bob Levy''' is a standup comedian who was a frequent on and off air contributor to the Sirius XM radio show from the show's debut until around 2009. He hosted the ''Miserable Men'' show and created a series of [[roasts]] for Stern show personalities such as [[Gary Dell'Abate]], [[Artie Lange]], and Wack Packers such as [[Daniel Carver]]. The placement, frequency and number of [[Promotion (marketing)|plugs]] given during the Stern show for Levy's off-air efforts was a constant source of tension, especially after the availability of plugs was severely restricted.<ref>See main article [[Reverend Bob Levy]]</ref> After Artie's departure, Levy complained on air that some details of the situation were being "covered up" and blamed Howard Stern for the suicide attempt. Levy's departure from the Stern channels soon followed and he is almost never mentioned on the air.<ref>[http://www.wcqj.com/bob-levy-blames-howard-stern-for-artie-langes-suicide-attempt-and-quits-the-miserable-men-show Bob Levy blames Howard Stern for Artie Lange's suicide attempt and quits The Miserable Men Show]. wcqj.com (2010-04-23). Retrieved on 2012-06-05.</ref>
===Former ''Howard 101'' hosts=== ====Scott Ferrall==== {{Main|Scott Ferrall}} '''Scott Ferrall''' was the host of ''The Scott Ferrall Show'' heard weekdays at 8 pm EST on Howard 101.<ref name="SiriusH101">[http://www.sirius.com/howard101 Hear the Revolution – Howard Stern – Entertainment – Howard 101 – SiriusXM Satellite Radio – SiriusXM Radio]. Sirius.com. Retrieved on 2012-06-05.</ref> It aired from 2006 to 2012.
====Abe Kanan==== '''Abe Kanan''' is host of ''The Abe Kanan Show'', which aired on Howard 101 weekends and late nights. Kanan's show originates in Chicago. It began as a series of podcasts and was picked up by the Stern channels in February 2011 and lasted until December 2013. He now hosts his own podcast titled "Abe Kanan On Hold".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chicagoradioandmedia.com/news/1686-the-abe-kanan-show-picked-up-by-siriusxm-set-to-air-weekly |title='The Abe Kanan Show' Picked Up By Sirius/XM; Set To Air Weekly | Chicagoland Radio and Media |publisher=Chicagoradioandmedia.com |date=June 7, 2011 |accessdate=June 5, 2012}}</ref>
====Riley Martin==== {{Main|Riley Martin}} '''Riley Martin''' (May 9, 1946 – December 2015) was a self-described [[Extraterrestrial life|alien]] [[contactee]], author, and host of ''The Riley Martin Show'' heard Tuesdays at Midnight EST on Howard 101.<ref name="SiriusH101" />
====Jackie Martling==== {{Main|Jackie Martling}} '''Jackie Martling''' is the former head writer and in-studio laugh track of ''The Howard Stern Show''. He was the host of ''Jackie's Joke Hunt''. The show, co-hosted by fellow [[New York Friars' Club|Friar]] Ian Karr, premiered on October 3, 2006 at 7 pm [[North American Eastern Standard Time|EST]]. It continues to air, live, every Tuesday at 7 pm EST on Sirius Howard 101, with reruns scheduled for Thursday mornings at 12 am EST and Saturday afternoons at 2 pm EST. ''Jackie's Joke Hunt'' has since been canceled along with many other shows that have been cut during 2014–2015.
====Mutt==== '''Mutt''' is the founder of the Stern Fan Network message board and host of ''The Super Fan Roundtable'' heard Wednesday's at 7 pm EST on Howard 101.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sternfannetwork.com/forum/faq.php?faq=contact#faq_contactsfrt |title=Super Fan Roundtable |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716135437/http://www.sternfannetwork.com/forum/faq.php?faq=contact |archivedate=July 16, 2011 |df=mdy}}</ref>
====Red Peters==== {{Main|Red Peters}} '''Red Peters''' is the host of ''The Red Peters Music Comedy Hour'' which airs periodically on Howard 101. Peters (real name Douglas Stevens) is a Boston-based songwriter/comedian who specializes in a musical form best described as "lounge smut" and the show presents a compilation of songs packed with scat jokes and double-entendres.
====Jeff Probst & Natalie Maines==== {{Main|Jeff Probst|Natalie Maines}} '''Jeff Probst''' is best known for his role as the host of the U.S. version of the reality show ''[[Survivor (U.S. TV series)|Survivor]]'' and '''Natalie Maines''' is best known as the lead singer of [[The Dixie Chicks]]. Together after each season of Survivor has wrapped-up they host a two-hour ''Celebrity Superfan Roundtable'' on Howard 101, where they bring in big name Hollywood stars such as actor [[David Arquette]], LA weatherbabe [[Jillian Reynolds]], producer [[Damon Lindelof]], singer [[Mark McGrath]], actor [[Jerry O'Connell]], actor [[Ryan Phillippe]], comedian [[Sarah Silverman]], and actor [[Steven Weber (actor)|Steven Weber]] to discuss their favorite moments on the Stern show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sirius.com/howardstern|title=Howard Stern on Sirrus|publisher=Sirrus satellite radio|accessdate=December 11, 2010}}</ref>
====Jay Thomas==== {{Main|Jay Thomas}} '''Jay Thomas''' was the host of ''The Jay Thomas Show'' on Howard 101 from 2005 until his 2017 death.
====Chuck Zito==== {{Main|Chuck Zito}}
'''Chuck Zito''' is an actor, amateur [[boxing|boxer]], [[martial art]]ist, celebrity [[bodyguard]], [[stunt double|stuntman]], former boxing trainer and former president of the New York City chapter of the [[Hells Angels]], and is host of the periodic ''Chuck Zito's View'' on Howard 101.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.maxboxing.com/Gerbasi/gerbasi032503.asp |title=Chuck Zito: Friend of the Game |author=Thomas Gerbasi |publisher=MaxBoxing |date=March 25, 2003 |accessdate=November 1, 2007 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080127115044/http://www.maxboxing.com/Gerbasi/gerbasi032503.asp |archivedate=January 27, 2008 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Former Howard 100 News staff=== ====Penny Crone==== {{Main|Penny Crone}}
====Brad Driver==== '''Brad Driver''' is the News Director at Howard 100 News and is responsible for managing the news team. He has held the position since December 2006.
====Lisa Glasberg==== {{Main|Lisa Glasberg}} A former co-host with [[Doctor Dré]] and [[Ed Lover]] on New York hip-hop radio station [[WQHT]]-FM, known as Hot 97, Lisa Glasberg, known informally as [[Lisa G]], was an on-air reporter for Howard 100 until February 2015, updating live news headlines each morning and filing reports for hourly [[Howard 100]] news updates.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0792141|title=Howard Stern on Demand|publisher=IMDB}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sirius.com/lisag|title=LisaG Bio|publisher=Siruis}}</ref> Glasberg is a native of Woodmere, New York.
====Ralph Howard==== '''Ralph Howard''' was the anchor who read the Howard 100 News every afternoon. In September 2010, he underwent lung transplant surgery. He retired from the show on May 30, 2013 after 53 years of news broadcasting. Howard is married to Broadway actress and longtime [[Charles Busch]] collaborator, [[Julie Halston]].<ref name="Pulmonary Fibrosis">{{cite web |url = http://www.pulmonaryfibrosis.org/node/433 |title = Howard Stern Show News Reporter Transplanted for IPF |publisher = pulmonaryfibrosis.org }}</ref>
====Steve Langford==== '''Steve Langford'''
====Michael Morales==== '''Michael "High Pitch Mike" Morales''' was Howard 100 News producer, reporter, and on-air regular. Publicly came out as gay on the show.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://howardstern.com/rundown.hs?month=December&day=1&year=2008&x=31&y=5 |title=MIKE COMES CLEAN The Howard Stern Show for December 1, 2008 |date=December 1, 2008 |publisher=HowardStern.Com (Official Site) |accessdate=January 7, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206143605/http://howardstern.com/rundown.hs?month=December&day=1&year=2008&x=31&y=5 |archivedate=December 6, 2008 }}</ref> Mike has an unusual, squeaky voice, leading to his nickname.
===TV staff=== ====Ralph Cirella==== [[File:Ralph Cirella by Gage Skidmore.jpg|thumb|Ralph Cirella]] '''Ralph Cirella''' was paid by Howard TV to be Howard Stern's personal stylist, a job he previously held for Stern's [[E!]] show. Cirella was first hired to construct a "talking penis", for a broadcast at the [[Felt Forum]] on New Year's Eve 1986.<ref name='act2guide2' /> He has been a listener since Stern's time at [[WNBC (AM)|WNBC]] from 1982 to 1985.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/news08/12-22.htm |title=THoHS:A2 – Howard's New Style And Ralph Cirella. December 24, 2008. 8:05 am |publisher=MarksFriggin.com }}</ref> Cirella did not make on-screen appearances until 1990, when he worked on costumes, special effects and make up on ''[[Howard Stern television shows#The Howard Stern Show (WWOR)|The Howard Stern Show]]'' on [[WWOR-TV]]. In his book, [[Miss America (book)|''Miss America'']], Howard Stern calls Ralph the most universally hated member of his staff. Throughout 2006, Cirella briefly co-hosted the now defunct ''The Friday Show'' with [[Gary Dell'Abate]] and [[Jon Hein]], on [[Howard 100 and Howard 101]]. He was also the host of "Geek Time" which aired on Howard 101.
====Scott DePace==== '''Scott DePace''' was the television director for the daily broadcast of ''The Howard Stern Show'' for [[Howard TV]]. His wife, Pamela, won an [[Emmy]] for her work on ''[[The Daily Show]]''.
====Scott Einziger==== '''Scott Einziger''' is a former Producer of Stern's syndicated Saturday night TV show and E! show. Left the show in November 2001 to become a producer on [[The Amazing Race]]. He has since worked on other reality shows such as [[Kid Nation]], [[Big Brother (U.S.)|Big Brother]], and [[Are You Hot?]]. Stern sued Einziger and his production company for ripping off his "The Evaluators" which Are You Hot? mirrored.<ref name="Einziger">{{cite news|url=http://www.realitytvworld.com/news/howard-stern-settles-are-you-hot-lawsuit-1529.php|title=Howard Stern settles 'Are You Hot?' lawsuit|author=Wade Paulsen|date=August 7, 2003|publisher=Reality TV World}}</ref>
====Mike Gange==== '''Mike Gange''' started at the show as an intern, and, after years of toil, worked his way up to cameraman/interviewer for the former Stern TV show on [[E!]] Gange then became supervising producer for Howard TV.
====Doug Goodstein==== '''Doug Z. Goodstein''' was Stern's [[E!]] show producer and executive producer for Howard TV On Demand.
====Robin Radzinski==== '''Robin Radzinski''' is a former [[E!]] network executive and former Producer of Stern's E! show who has also worked for [[G4 (Canadian TV channel)|G4]], [[HBO]], and [[TBS (U.S. TV channel)|TBS]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://rradzinski.com/ |accessdate=October 11, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100612121851/http://rradzinski.com/ |archivedate=June 12, 2010 }}</ref>
===Former bosses=== ====Randy Bongarten==== '''Randy Bongarten'''<ref>{{cite web|last=Kunen |first=James S. |url=http://www.people.com/people/archive/article/0,,20088964,00.html |title=Howard Stern |work=People |date=October 22, 1984 |accessdate=June 5, 2012}}</ref> is a radio executive and former Vice-President and [[General Manager]] at [[WNBC (AM)|WNBC]] who was later promoted to be President of the entire [[NBC Radio Network]]. Robin Quivers said that Randy's tenure at WNBC were the "good years" at the station because Randy "understood the show, and was interested in letting the talent do the things that would let the talent be successful."<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20110713215346/http://www.liveblogginghowardstern.com/page/4/ Family Feud]. Liveblogginghowardstern.com</ref>
====Tom Chiusano==== '''Tom Chiusano''' was the general manager at [[WNYL (FM)|WXRK]], the frequent target of Stern show jokes, and in the later years of the show the master of the "dump button" to prevent content he deemed inappropriate from reaching the airwaves.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.marksfriggin.com/whoswho/tom.htm |title=Who's Who |publisher=MarksFriggin.com |accessdate=2015-05-20}}</ref> Chiusano remained at WXRK when Stern and company moved to Sirius, and after several format changes at his station, he eventually announced his retirement in January 2008.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/television/exec-made-k-rock-roll-departing-article-1.341172|title=Exec who made K-Rock roll forced to step down|author=David Hinckley|publisher=NY Daily News|date=January 19, 2008|accessdate=June 12, 2012|location=New York}}</ref>
====John Hayes==== {{Main|John Hayes (radio)}} '''John Hayes''' is a radio executive, famously named "The [[Incubus]]" by Howard during his days as Vice-President and [[General Manager]] at [[WNBC (AM)|WNBC]] replacing Randy Bongarten. He and Kevin Metheny were portrayed by [[Paul Giamatti]] as a [[composite character]] under the name Kenny "Pig Vomit" Rushton in the 1997 movie, ''[[Private Parts (1997 film)|Private Parts]]''. It was Hayes who actually fired Stern from WNBC-AM in 1985 on the orders of [[NBC]] network executives. In 2002, Hayes once again pulled Stern's show from [[CILQ-FM]] in Toronto.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://business.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20080825.rmexit0825/BNStory/specialROBmagazine/home |work=Globe and Mail |location=Toronto |first=Gordon |last=Pitts |title=The guy who fired Howard Stern—twice—leaves Corus |date=August 25, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090422080228/http://business.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20080825.rmexit0825/BNStory/specialROBmagazine/home |archivedate=April 22, 2009 }}</ref> Hayes proudly calls himself "the man who fired Howard Stern twice."<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20160304071724/http://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/the-guy-who-fired-howard-sterntwiceleaves-corus/article705343/comments/ ] </ref>
====Kevin Metheny==== {{Main|Kevin Metheny}} '''Kevin Metheny''' (June 6, 1954 – October 3, 2014) was a radio executive, famously named "Pig Virus" by Howard during his days as [[Program Director]] at [[WNBC (AM)|WNBC]]. He and his replacement John Hayes were portrayed by [[Paul Giamatti]] as a [[composite character]] under the name Kenny "Pig Vomit" Rushton in the 1997 movie, ''[[Private Parts (1997 film)|Private Parts]]''.<ref name="cleveland">{{cite news|url=http://www.cleveland.com/entertainment/index.ssf/2010/04/kevin_methany_aka_pig_virus_ri.html|title=Kevin Metheny, a.k.a. 'Pig Virus,' riles WGN Radio's Chicago fan base|work=[[The Plain Dealer]]|author=Michael Norman|date=April 30, 2010}}</ref>
====Tim Sabean==== '''Tim Sabean''' was the Senior Vice President of the Howard Stern Channels for Howard 100 & 101. He managed the channels and their personnel for Howard. Before coming to Sirius he was the program director at Stern's [[Philadelphia]] affiliate [[WYSP-FM]]. Sabean's departure from the show was never formally announced, but he is no longer listed as a staff or front office member on the Stern show website.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.howardstern.com/profiles#radio-staff |title=Meet the Howard Stern Show Crew |publisher=HowardStern.com |date=2015-05-13 |accessdate=2015-05-20}}</ref> The last entry on his official Twitter feed was on 1 August 2013<ref>{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/TimSabean |title=TimSabean (@TimSabean) |publisher=Twitter.com |accessdate=2015-05-20}}</ref> and his last on-air appearance was around that time.
On September 9, 2013 it was announced by Sirius/XM that he'd been promoted to Senior Vice President of all the Entertainment and Comedy channels.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allaccess.com/net-news/archive/story/122116/siriusxm-assigns-three-top-talk-execs-to-new-roles |title=SiriusXM Assigns Three Top Talk Execs To New Roles |publisher=AllAccess.com |date=2013-09-09 |accessdate=2015-05-20}}</ref>
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.howardstern.com/ Howard Stern's Official Web Site] at HowardStern.com
{{Howard_Stern Show}}

revision.text:
{{Unreferenced|date=January 2017}} [[File:Norwegian ISAF soldiers.jpg|thumb|Norwegian ISAF soldiers wearing M98 battle uniform]] '''M/98''' is the standard [[Norway|Norwegian]] Battle Uniform, used by the [[Norwegian Army|Army]], [[Royal Norwegian Air Force|Air Force]], and [[Home Guard (Norway)|Home Guard]].
It is an updated version of the older model M/75, and is used together with different hats according to military branch. The [[uniform]] consists of jacket and trousers and comes in the Norwegian [[Military Camouflage|camouflage]]. The jacket has two breast pockets and two big hand pockets, both with flap and a sewn on velcro above left breast pocket for the name tag. The trousers have regular pockets for hands - one back pocket and cargo pockets with flap. In addition to the regular Norwegian camouflage in green, brown and a darker green color, a special desert pattern has also been developed for the wars in [[War in Afghanistan (2001–2014)|Afghanistan]] and [[Iraq War|Iraq]].
The desert pattern consists of light green, brown and dark brown.
The M/98 is commonly used in [[garrison]] and only rarely used in the field.
The Norwegian army has a separate field uniform consisting of olive drab (and also camouflage) pants and a Norwegian camouflage field jacket.
<!-- Unsourced image removed: [[File:Tirs09_tl_05999_64014a.jpg]] -->
[[Category:Military equipment of Norway]] [[Category:Military uniforms]]
{{Norway-mil-stub}}

revision.text:
{{More citations needed|date=April 2018}} {{Infobox former subdivision |native_name = ''Neuschwabenland'' |conventional_long_name = New Swabia |common_name = New Swabia | |subdivision = Protectorate |nation = Nazi Germany |status_text = Unrecognized Antarctic claim of [[Nazi Germany]] |country = |era = World War II |status = |empire = |government_type = |year_start = 1939 |year_end = 1945 |life_span = 1939–1945 | |event_start = Declared |date_start = 19 January |event_end = Surrender of Germany |date_end = 8 May |event_post = |date_post = | |s1 = Queen Maud Land |flag_s1 = Flag of Norway.svg | |image_flag = Flag of German Reich (1935–1945).svg |flag = |image_coat = Emblem of the Nazi German Antarctic Expedition.svg |symbol = |symbol_type = Expedition logo
(1938-39) |image_map = NewSwabiaMap.jpg |image_map_caption = Territory comprising claimed German territory New Swabia marked in red }} {{Antarctic expeditions sidebar}} '''New Swabia''' ([[Norwegian language|Norwegian]] and {{lang-de|Neuschwabenland}}) is a [[cartography|cartographic]] name sometimes given to an area of [[Antarctica]] between [[20th meridian east|20°E]] and [[10th meridian west|10°W]] in [[Queen Maud Land]], which is claimed as a Norwegian [[dependent territory]] under the [[Antarctic Treaty System]]. New Swabia was explored by Germany in early 1939 and named after that expedition's ship, the {{MS|Schwabenland|1925|2}}, itself named after the [[Germany|German]] region of [[Swabia]].McGonigal, David, ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=8bFcJgX0lIUC&pg=PA347 Antarctica]'', frances lincoln ltd, 2009, {{ISBN|0-7112-2980-5}}, {{ISBN|978-0-7112-2980-8}}, p 367{{cite news |url=http://www.polarhistorie.no/artikler/2008/annekteringen%20av%20dronning%20maud%20land/print_artikler_view |first=Turi |last=Widerøe |work=Norsk Polarhistorie |language=Norwegian |title=Annekteringen av Dronning Maud Land |year=2008 |accessdate=15 July 2011}} ==Background== Like many other countries, [[German Empire|Germany]] sent expeditions to the Antarctic region in the late 19th and early 20th centuries, most of which were scientific. The late 19th century expeditions to the [[Southern Ocean]], [[South Georgia Island|South Georgia]], the [[Kerguelen Islands]], and the [[Crozet Islands]] were astronomical, meteorological, and hydrological, mostly in close collaboration with scientific teams from other countries. As the 19th century ended Germany began to focus on Antarctica. The first German expedition to Antarctica was the [[Gauss expedition]] from 1901 to 1903. Led by Arctic veteran and geology professor [[Erich von Drygalski]], this was the first expedition to use a [[hot-air balloon]] in Antarctica. It also found and named [[Kaiser Wilhelm II Land]]. The second German Antarctic expedition (1911–1912) was led by [[Wilhelm Filchner]] with a goal of crossing Antarctica to learn if it was one piece of land. As happened with other such early attempts, the crossing failed before it even began. The expedition discovered and named the [[Luitpold Coast]] and the [[Filchner Ice Shelf]]. A German [[whaling]] fleet was put to sea in 1937 and, upon its successful return in early 1938, plans for a third German Antarctic expedition were drawn up. ==German Antarctic Expedition (1938–1939)== [[File:Schwabenland.jpg|thumb|MS ''Schwabenland'' in 1938]] The third German Antarctic Expedition (1938–1939) was led by [[Alfred Ritscher]] (1879–1963), a captain in the [[Kriegsmarine|German Navy]]. The main purpose was to find an area in Antarctica for a German whaling station, as a way to increase Germany's production of fat. [[Whale oil]] was then the most important raw material for the production of [[margarine]] and [[soap]] in Germany and the country was the second largest purchaser of Norwegian whale oil, importing some 200,000 metric tonnes annually. Besides the disadvantage of being dependent on [[imports]], it was thought that Germany would soon be at war, which was considered to put too much strain on Germany's [[foreign currency reserve]]s. Another goal was to scout possible locations for a German naval base.[http://www.histarmar.com.ar/Antartida/Base-Hitler/LaBaseAntarticadeHitler.pdf ''Hitler's Antarctic base: the myth and the reality''], by Colin Summerhayes and Peter Beeching, [[Polar Record]], Volume 43 Issue 1, pp.1–21 Cambridge University Press, 2007. [[Image:Emblem of the Nazi German Antarctic Expedition.svg|thumb|1938–1939 expedition logo]] On 17 December 1938 the New Swabia Expedition left Hamburg for Antarctica aboard the MS ''Schwabenland'' (a freighter built in 1925 and renamed in 1934 after the [[Swabia]] region in southern Germany) which could also carry and catapult aircraft. The secret expedition had 33 members plus the ''Schwabenland'''s crew of 24. On 19 January 1939 the ship arrived at the [[Princess Martha Coast]], in an area which had lately been claimed by [[Norway]] as [[Queen Maud Land]] and began charting the region. Nazi German flags were placed on the sea ice along the coast. Naming the area ''Neu-Schwabenland'' after the ship, the expedition established a temporary base and in the following weeks teams walked along the coast recording claim reservations on hills and other significant landmarks. Seven photographic survey flights were made by the ship’s two [[Dornier Wal]] [[seaplane]]s named ''Passat'' and ''Boreas''.Boudewijn Büch. ''Eenzaam, Eilanden 2'' ('Lonely, Islands 2'), Holland 1994 About a dozen 1.2 meter-long aluminum arrows, with 30 centimeter steel cones and three upper stabilizer wings embossed with swastikas, were air dropped onto the ice at turning points of the flight polygons (these arrows had been tested on the [[Pasterze glacier]] in Austria before the expedition).Ritscher's expedition report, more information pending Eight more flights were made to areas of keen interest and on these trips some of the photos were taken with colour film. Altogether they flew over hundreds of thousands of square kilometres and took more than 16,000 aerial photographs, some of which were published after the war by Ritscher. The ice-free [[Schirmacher Oasis]], which now hosts the [[Maitri]] and [[Novolazarevskaya Station|Novolazarevskaya]] research stations, was spotted from the air by Richardheinrich Schirmacher (who named it after himself) shortly before the ''Schwabenland'' left the Antarctic coast on 6 February 1939. On its return trip to Germany the expedition made oceanographic studies near [[Bouvet Island]] and [[Fernando de Noronha]], arriving back in Hamburg on 11 April 1939. Meanwhile, the Norwegian government had learned about the expedition through reports from whalers along the coast of Queen Maud Land. Although some, notably Norwegian writer Bjarne Aagaard and German geographer Ernst Herrmann, have claimed that Germany never actually occupied the territory, it is well documented that Germany issued a decree about the establishment of a German Antarctic Sector called New Swabia after the expedition's return in August 1939. ===Geographic features mapped by the expedition=== {{Expand list|date=August 2009}} Because the area was first explored by a German expedition, the name ''Neuschwabenland'' (''New Swabia'') is still used for the region on some maps, as are many of the German names given to its geographic features.e.g., ''National Geographic Atlas of the World'', Eighth Edition, 2005 Some geographic features mapped by the expedition were not named until the [[Norwegian-British-Swedish Antarctic Expedition]] (NBSAE) (1949–1952), led by [[John Schjelderup Giæver]]. Others were not named until they were remapped from aerial photographs taken by the [[Sixth Norwegian Antarctic Expedition|Norwegian Antarctic Expedition]] (1958–1959). [http://geonames.usgs.gov/pls/gnispublic/ USGS GNIS] {{div col|colwidth=22em}} *[[Ahlmann Ridge]] *[[Alan Peak]] *[[Aurdalsegga Ridge]] *[[Austvorren Ridge]] *[[Boreas Nunatak]] *[[Borg Massif]] *[[Conrad Mountains]] *[[Drygalski Mountains]] *[[Filchner Mountains]] *[[Fimbul Ice Shelf]] *[[Gessner Peak]] *[[Gburek Peaks]] *[[Gneiskopf Peak]] *[[Habermehl Peak]] *[[Humboldt Mountains (Antarctica)|Humboldt Mountains]] *[[Isdalen Valley]] *[[Isdalsegga Ridge]] *[[Isfossnipa Peak]] *[[Ising Glacier]] *[[Istind Peak]] *[[Kraul Mountains]] *[[Lake Untersee]] *[[Mount Dallmann]] *[[Mount Krüger]] *[[Mount Neustruyev]] *[[Mount Zimmermann]] *[[Mount Zuckerhut]] *[[Mühlig-Hofmann Mountains]] *New Swabia *[[Orvin Mountains]] *[[Payer Mountains]] *[[Penck Trough]] *[[Petermann Ranges (Antarctica)|Petermann Ranges]] *[[Preuschoff Range]] *[[Ritscher Peak]] *[[Ritscher Upland]] *[[Saetet Cirque]] *[[Sandeggtind Peak]] *[[Schirmacher Oasis]] *[[Shatskiy Hill]] *[[Stabben Mountain]] *[[Storkvarvet Mountain]] *[[Südliche Petermann Range]] *[[Sverdrup Mountains]] *[[Terningen Peak]] *[[Tindeklypa]] *[[Vorposten Peak]] *[[Weyprecht Mountains]] *[[Wohlthat Mountains]] *[[Zhil'naya Mountain]] *[[Zwiesel Mountain]] {{div col end}} [[File:Map of Antarctica with Neuschwabenland.jpg|thumb|German map of Antarctica (1941) showing Neuschwabenland]] ===Aftermath=== Germany made no formal territorial claims to New Swabia.Heinz Schön, ''Mythos Neu-Schwabenland. Für Hitler am Südpol'', Bonus, Selent 2004, p. 106, {{ISBN|3-935962-05-3}} No whaling station or other lasting bases were built there by Germany until the [[Georg-von-Neumayer-Station]], a research facility, was established in 1981. Germany's current [[Neumayer-Station III]] is also in the region. New Swabia is a [[Cartography|cartographic]] area of [[Queen Maud Land]] which within Norway is administered as a Norwegian [[dependent territory]] under the [[Antarctic Treaty System]] by the Polar Affairs Department of the [[Minister of Justice and the Police (Norway)|Ministry of Justice and the Police]]. ==See also== *[[List of Antarctic expeditions]] *[[Operation Highjump]] ==References== {{Reflist|2}} ==Literature== * D. T. Murphy, ''German exploration of the polar world. A history, 1870–1940'' (Nebraska 2002). ==External links== * [http://www.ddghansa-shipsphotos.de/schwarzenfels300.htm Photographs of the MS Schwabenland and its seaplanes] (text in German) * [http://www.seefunknetz.de/dofw.htm More photographs of the MS Schwabenland] (text in German) * [[Erich von Drygalski]] and the [http://www.south-pole.com/p0000085.htm 1901–03 German Antarctic Expedition], [[Scott Polar Research Institute]] * [[Wilhelm Filchner]] and the [http://www.south-pole.com/p0000103.htm 1911–12 German Antarctic Expedition], Scott Polar Research Institute * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110626153457/http://141.74.33.52/stagn/Antarctic_Maps/Documents/DGK_1986_Reihe_E_Heft_24_Teil_1.pdf Kartographische Arbeiten und deutsche Namengebung in Neuschwabenland, Antarktis] {{Antarctic territorial claims}} {{Antarctica navbox}} {{Polar exploration|state=collapsed}} {{Former German colonies}} {{coord|72|00|S|5|00|E|display=title}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2011}} {{Authority control}} [[Category:History of Antarctica]] [[Category:Regions of Queen Maud Land]] [[Category:Research and development in Nazi Germany]] [[Category:Germany and the Antarctic]] [[Category:1938 in Antarctica]] [[Category:1939 in Antarctica]] [[Category:1939 establishments in Antarctica]] [[Category:1945 disestablishments in Antarctica]] [[Category:1939 establishments in Germany]] [[Category:1945 disestablishments in Germany]]

revision.text:
{{Use Pakistani English|date=March 2018}} {{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox Union |name= PLF |country= [[Pakistan]] |affiliation= [[World Federation of Trade Unions]]
[[Athens]], [[Greece]] |members= 90,000 |full_name= Pakistan Labour Federation |native_name= |image= |founded= 1974 |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= [[Lahore]], Pakistan |people= Asif F. Vardag, President
Haji Muhammed Saeed, Secretary General
Hamad Maqsood Gill,Senior Vice President
Atia Saleem, Chairwoman[http://www.wftucentral.org/plf-pakistan-demanded-the-government-to-accept-the-demands-of-the-nurses/ Pakistan Labour Federation (PLF) demands from the Government to accept the Demands of the Nurses] World Federation of Trade Unions website, Published 27 March 2014, Retrieved 2 March 2018 |website= |footnotes= }} The '''Pakistan Labour Federation''' (PLF) is the largest [[national trade union center]] in [[Pakistan]]. It was founded in 1974.[http://labourwatchpakistan.com/overview-of-trade-unions-in-pakistan/ Overview of Trade Unions in Pakistan including Pakistan Labour Federation on Labour Watch Pakistan website] Published 20 April 2011, Retrieved 2 March 2018[http://www.world-psi.org/en/pakistan-labour-federation-joins-campaign-end-violence-work Pakistan Labour Federation joins campaign to end violence at work] world-psi.org website, Published 14 February 2018, Retrieved 2 March 2018 Pakistan Labour Federation is affiliated with the larger world body of trade unions known as [[World Federation of Trade Unions]] based in [[Athens]], [[Greece]]. == References == {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Pakistan Labour Federation}} [[Category:Trade unions in Pakistan]] [[Category:Labour history of Pakistan]] [[Category:Labour relations in Pakistan]] [[Category:World Federation of Trade Unions]] [[Category:Trade unions established in 1974]] [[Category:1974 establishments in Pakistan]] {{Pakistan-org-stub}} {{Asia-trade-union-stub}}

{{Expand Italian|Arcidiocesi di Algeri|date=November 2014}} {{Infobox diocese | jurisdiction = Archdiocese | name = Algiers | latin = Archidioecesis Algeriensis | local = Archidiocèse de Alger | image = Dioc Alger ter.PNG | caption = Map of the Archdiocese of Algiers | country = {{flag|Algeria}} | province = Algiers | metropolitan = [[Algiers]] | area_km2 = 54,701 | area_sqmi = 21,128 | population = 10,585,000 | population_as_of = 2012 | catholics = 1,530 | catholics_percent = 0.0 | rite = [[Roman Rite|Roman]] | established = {{start date|1838|08|10}} | cathedral = [[Cathédrale du Sacré-Cœur d'Alger]], Algiers | priests = 45 | pope = {{Incumbent pope}} | bishop = [[Paul Jacques Marie Desfarges]]
Archbishop of Algiers | bishop_title = Archbishop | metro_archbishop = [[Paul Jacques Marie Desfarges]] | website = [http://www.ada.asso.dz/articles.php?lng=fr&pg=66] }} [[File:Sacred heart of Algiers as seen from Didouche Mourad.jpg|thumb|Cathédrale du Sacré-Cœur d'Alger]] [[Image:NOTRE DAME D'AFRIQUE.ALGER.jpg|thumb|right|The basilica of [[Notre Dame d'Afrique]] in [[Algiers]]]] The '''Archdiocese of Algiers''' ({{lang-la|Archidioecesis Algeriensis}}, {{lang-fr|Archidiocèse de Alger }}) is the [[Metropolitan bishop|metropolitan]] [[Episcopal See|see]] for the [[ecclesiastical province]] of [[Algiers]] in [[Algeria]]. ==History== * August 10, 1838: Established as Diocese of Algiers from [[Diocese of Islas Canarias]] in [[Spain]] * 1838: United with [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Iulia Caesarea|Diocese of Iulia Caesarea]] * July 25, 1866: Promoted as Metropolitan Archdiocese of Algiers ==Special churches== La Cathédrale du Sacré-Cœur d'Alger (Sacred Heart Cathedral of Algiers) a concrete Modernist church, was built in 1956. It became a cathedral in 1962, replacing the French colonial Cathedral of St. Philip of Algiers, when that 1612 building was reconverted to the Ketchaoua Mosque. The Cathedral of St. Philip of Algiers was established by converting the [[Ketchaoua Mosque]] in 1845, but was reconverted to the Ketchaoua Mosque in 1962. There is also a Minor Basilica at the Basilique de [[Notre Dame d'Afrique]] in Algiers. ==Ordinaries== === Apostolic Vicars of Algiers === # [[Philippe le Vacher]], [[Congregation of the Mission|CM]] (1651 – 17 July 1662) # [[Benjamin Huguier]], [[Congregation of the Mission|CM]] (1662 – April 1663) # [[Jean Le Vacher]], [[Congregation of the Mission|CM]] (23 May 1668 – 29 July 1683) # [[Michel de Montmasson]], [[Congregation of the Mission|CM]] (8 January 1685 – 5 July 1688) # [[José Gianola]], [[Trinitarian Order|O.SS.T]] (1690–1693) # [[Yves Laurence]], [[Congregation of the Mission|CM]] (September 1693 – 11 March 1705) # [[Lambert Duchêne]], [[Congregation of the Mission|CM]] (1705 – December 1736) # [[Ghaleb Moussa Abdalla Bader]] (24 May 2008 – 23 May 2015) # [[Paul Jacques Marie Desfarges]], [[Society of Jesus|SJ]] (24 December 2016 – ) === Auxiliary bishops === * [[Pierre-Jean-Joseph Soubiranne]] (22 December 1871 – 27 February 1880) * [[Salvator-Alexandre-Félix-Carmel Brincat]] (28 June 1889 – 1903) * [[Alexandre Piquemal]] (26 February 1909 – 4 June 1920) * [[Paul Pierre Pinier]] (13 December 1947 – 27 March 1954) * [[Gaston Marie Jacquier]] (4 December 1960 – 8 July 1976) === Bishops who were priests of the diocese === This list contains men, living and deceased, who were priests of the Archdiocese of Algiers before becoming bishops in other dioceses. * [[Victor-Félix Bernadou]] (priest: 19 December 1840 – 7 April 1862) * [[Alphonse Émile Georger]] (priest: 29 June 1965 – 10 July 1998) * [[Gaston Marie Jacquier]] (priest: 18 December 1926 – 4 December 1960) * [[Henri Antoine Marie Teissier]] (priest: 24 March 1955 – 30 November 1972)) ==Suffragan dioceses== * [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Constantine|Diocese of Constantine]] * [[Roman Catholic Diocese of Oran|Diocese of Oran]] ==See also== * [[List of Catholic dioceses in Algeria]] ==Sources== {{Wikisource1913CatholicEnc|Algiers}} * [http://www.gcatholic.org/dioceses/diocese/algi0.htm GCatholic.org] ==External links== * [http://www.catholic-hierarchy.org/diocese/dalge.html catholic-hierarchy.org] {{R-C dioceses in Algeria}}{{Archdiocese of Algiers}}{{Africa-RC-diocese-stub}} {{Algeria-stub}}{{coord|36.7674|N|3.0544|E|source:wikidata-and-enwiki-cat-tree_region:DZ|display=title}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Algiers}} [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses in Algeria]] [[Category:Algiers|Roman Catholic]] [[Category:Religious organizations established in 1838]] [[Category:Roman Catholic dioceses and prelatures established in the 19th century]] [[Category:Roman Catholic Ecclesiastical Province of Alger| ]] [[Category:1838 establishments in Algeria]] [[Fr:Paul Pierre Pinier|Paul Pierre Pinier]]

{{multiple issues| {{more citations needed|date=September 2014}} {{tone|date=March 2010}} }} {{Infobox film | director = [[Henry Barakat]] | writer = [[Rahbani Brothers]] | starring = [[Fairuz]]
[[Nasri Shamseddine]]
[[Huda (actress)|Huda]]
[[Assi Rahbani]]
[[Berj Fazalian]]
[[Salah Tizani]]
[[Salwa Haddad]] | music = [[Rahbani Brothers]] | studio = [[Phenicia Films]] | distributor= [[United Trade and Cinema Company]] | released = {{start date|1967}} | runtime = 115 minutes | country = Lebanon | language = Arabic }} '''''Safar Barlik''''' (in [[Arabic language|Arabic]] سفر برلك meaning ''The Exile'') is a 1967 Lebanese [[musical theatre|musical]] and a [[war film]] directed by [[Henry Barakat]]. The film stars [[Fairuz]], [[Nasri Shamseddine]], [[Huda (actress)|Huda]], [[Assi Rahbani]], [[Berj Fazlian]], [[Salah Tizani]] and [[Salwa Haddad]]. It was filmed in the northern village of [[Beit Chabab]] and [[Douma, Lebanon|Douma]] in Lebanon. ==Plot== The film is set in 1914. It displays the struggles of a Lebanese village to smuggle wheat under [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] oppression.{{cite news|url=http://www.reorientmag.com/2012/08/sounds-from-the-golden-age/ |title=Sounds from the Golden Age |first=Arie |last=Amaya-Akkermans |publisher=Reorient Magazine |date=August 23, 2012}} ==Cast== * [[Fairuz]] as Adla * [[Nasri Shamseddine]] as Elmoukhtar * [[Huda (actress)|Huda]] as Zoumorod * [[Assi Rahbani]] as Abou Ahmed * [[Berj Fazlian]] as Re'fat Bek * [[Rafic Sabeii]] as Abou Darwish * [[Salwa Haddad]] as Oum Youssef * [[Joseph Nassif]] as Elhasoon * [[Layla Karam]] as Zahia * [[Salah Tizani]] as Fares * [[Abdulallah Homsi]] as Asad * [[Ahmed Khalifa]] as Haji Noula * [[Ihssan Sadek]] as Abdo ==Songs== Songs from the film include: *“Ya Tayr” (Oh Bird! يا طير ) *“Allamouni Henni Allamouni” (they taught me your love علّموني هنّي علّموني ) *“Ya Ahl El Dar” (Lords of the mansion يا أهل الدار ). == Safarberlik, historical meaning== [[Wikipedia talk:Articles for creation/Safarberlik|Safarberlik]] (or Seferberlik) is the historical practice during the late wars that the Ottoman government engaged into during the later phases of its empire. Safarberlik signifies conscription practices for the Balkan wars and World War I and the same term invokes all memories associated with war experience. == References == {{Reflist}} {{authority control}} [[Category:1967 films]] [[Category:Lebanese films]] [[Category:1960s war films]] [[Category:Films set in 1914]] [[Category:Films directed by Henry Barakat]] {{Lebanon-film-stub}} {{war-film-stub}}

{{other use|Thomas Sturge (disambiguation)}}
'''Thomas Sturge''' (1787-1866) was a British oil merchant, shipowner, cement manufacturer, railway company director, social reformer and philanthropist.
==Family background and early life==
Thomas Sturge was born in 1787, one of at least ten children of [[Thomas Sturge the elder]] (1749-1825), [[tallow]] chandler and oil merchant of [[Newington Butts]], about a mile south of [[London Bridge]]. Thomas the younger joined his father’s business early in the 19th century, as did at least three of his brothers, Nathan, George and Samuel. Thomas Sturge & Sons, oil merchants and [[spermaceti]] processors operated from premises near [[Elephant and Castle]], Newington Butts, until 1840.<ref>London Metropolitan Archives, index to the records of the Sun Fire Assurance Office, 1840.</ref>
He was a first cousin of social reformer and philanthropist [[Joseph Sturge]].
==Oil merchant and shipowner== [[File:Whaling of sperm whale.jpg|thumb|Hunting the sperm whale]] {{See also|Whaling in the United Kingdom}} Thomas Sturge junior had become the senior partner in the business by 1816, when he began to buy ships and send them to the Southern Whale Fishery to obtain [[whale oil]], seal oil and [[spermaceti]] for processing and sale in London.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://bswf.hull.ac.uk/Output.php?OWNER=Thomas+Sturge&Submit2=Submit |website=bswf.hull.ac.uk |title=British Southern Whale Fishery - Voyages}}</ref> He became the principal owner of at least 23 vessels, most of them [[History of whaling#Southern whale fishery|South Sea whalers]].<ref>Howard, p.414.</ref>
His [[Quaker]] faith and values were reflected in his business dealings. He tried to choose committed Christians to command his [[whaler|whale ships]] and in his sailing instructions gave his captains detailed advice on how to treat their crewmen.<ref>Howard, p.433.</ref> His vessels each seem to have been supplied with a small library and at least five of his vessels carried a "surgeon" or ship's doctor.<ref>Howard, p.425.</ref> One of these was Dr Thomas Beale who later wrote, ''The Natural History of the Sperm Whale'' (1839), which he dedicated to his employer.<ref>Thomas Beale, ''The Natural History of the Sperm Whale'', London, John Van Voorst, 1839; reprinted by The Holland Press, London, 1973, p.ix-x.</ref> Herman Melville drew on the book for his novel ''Moby Dick'' (1851).<ref>Howard P. Vincent, ''The trying-out of Moby Dick'', Houghton Miffin, Boston, 1949, p.128.</ref> The book also inspired three paintings of whaling scenes by [[J.M.W. Turner]], exhibited at the [[Royal Academy]] in 1845 and 1846.<ref>Beale (1973) dustjacket.</ref> Turner tried to sell them to his patron, oil merchant, shipowner and art collector [[Elhanan Bicknell]]. Bicknell was an associate and friend of Sturge at Newington Butts.<ref>[[Philip Hoare]], ‘’Leviathan or, the whale’’, London, 2009, p.250-1, 277.</ref>
==Social reformer and philanthropist== Sturge was a member of a committee to assist “distressed seaman” by 1818.<ref>''Morning Chronicle'', 9 January 1818.</ref> His firm donated £15 15 shillings in 1821 toward the cost of a suitable vessel to serve as a [[hospital ship|floating hospital]] for the “assistance and relief of sick and helpless seamen.”<ref>''Morning Chronicle'', 15 March 1821.</ref> The [[Seamen's Hospital Society]] was established that year, with [[William Wilberforce]] as one of the many vice presidents; Sturge was one of a couple of dozen men on its management committee, along with [[Zachary Macaulay]] and [[William Young (Royal Navy officer, born 1751)|Captain William Young]].<ref>{{cite book|title=The annual subscription charities and public societies in London|date=1823|page=24|url=https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=IR8HAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA24&dq#v=onepage&q&f=false|accessdate=28 April 2018}}</ref>
He was a member of the [[Anti-Slavery Society]] and substantial financial contributor to the cause.<ref>''Anti-Slavery Monthly Reporter'', 3, June 1829-December 1830, p.268; William Lloyd Garrison, ''The letters of William Lloyd Garrison; No union with the slaveholders, 1841-1849'', Cambridge, MA, 1974, p.187.</ref> Another member of the society was the historian and poitician [[Thomas Babington Macaulay]] (1800-1859) who became friends with Sturge. There were many [[Quakers in the abolition movement]]. Among these was his cousin the prominent [[anti-slavery]] abolitionist and philanthropist [[Joseph Sturge]] (1793-1859).
Thomas also made regular donations to a range of other charitable causes.<ref>Jones, p.480; "''The Times'', 3 May 1826 & 10 June 1823.</ref> He provided transport to missionaries going to the South Seas on his whaling ships. [[Robert Moffat (missionary)|Robert Moffat]] and his wife left their children in the care of Sturge and his invalid sister when they were in South Africa in the 1860s.<ref>Letter from Robert Moffatt dated 22 June 1861 to Thomas Sturge. Cambridge University Library, Add Ms8830 3/2/101.</ref> Thomas or his father, Thomas senior, was supporting the [[Deaf education#Great Britain|education of the deaf]] by May 1821.<ref>''List of Governors and officers of the asylum for the support and education of the deaf and dumb children of the poor'', London, 1821, p.175.</ref>
==Contributor to Antarctic exploration==
[[File:Balleny Islands.jpg|thumb|left|The Balleny Islands from a NASA satellite, December 2007. Sturge Island is the lower of the three main islands.]] In 1838 Sturge joined a group of London shipowners to purchase two vessels, the schooner ''Eliza Scott'' (154 tons) and the cutter ''Sabrina'' (54 tons). These were sent to the [[Antarctic]], under the overall command of Captain [[John Balleny]], to search for undiscovered offshore islands that might host seal colonies that could be harvested.<ref>"Discoveries in the Antarctic Ocean, in February 1839. Extracted from the Journal of the schooner Eliza Scott, commanded by Mr John Balleny, communicated by Charles Enderby, Esq., ''Journal of the Royal Geographical Society of London'', 9 (1839) pp.526-7.</ref> Among the discoveries made were a cluster five previously unknown islands. They were given the collective name of the [[Balleny Islands]] with individual islands named after those who had funded the expedition. [[Sturge Island]] is 23 miles long and 6 miles wide and permantly covered in a mantle of snow and ice.
==Cement producer== [[File:Knight, Bevan and Sturge cement works, Northfleet.jpg|thumb|right|The Knight, Bevan and Sturge Cement works in the second half of the 19th century.]]
In 1837 and 1838 he purchased two blocks of land on the Thames near [[Northfleet]] at a cost of £9,313.<ref>British Parliamentary Papers, HC 1842, Vol 25, p.26.</ref> On that 74 acre plot he built a [[cement]] works to make [[Portland cement]]. Construction of the [[cement kiln]]s started in 1851 and production began in 1853.<ref>http://www.cementkilns.co.uk/cement_kiln_bevans.html</ref>
==Railway investments==
He was interested in the building of new railways and in 1842 he spoke at a public meeting in favour of the construction of the Dean Forest and Gloucester railway line.<ref>''Berrows Worcestor Journal'', 15 December 1842.</ref> He became a significanr shareholder in the [[Eastern Union Railway]] Company and a major shareholder and director of the [[West Hartlepool]] Harbour and Railway Company.<ref>Sturge v Eastern Union Railway Co., 2 May - 2 June 1855, Hein online Legal Database, 7 DE G.M. & G. 162; House of Lords Sessional Papers, 1863, Vol.XXXIV, p.58.</ref>
==Later life== In 1842 he moved downriver to [[Northfleet]], where he had purchased Northfleet House, a mansion under construction, for £3900.<ref>Howard, p.423.</ref> Thomas Sturge the younger died there on April 14, 1866.<ref>Entry for Thomas Sturge, England & Wales National Probate Register, 1858-1966.</ref> He never married and most of his estate, valued at about £180,000, was left to his brother George.<ref>A.J. Francis, ''The cement industry, 1796-1914: a history'', Newton Abbott, 1978, p.165.</ref>
==Notes== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * British Southern Whale Fishery web site, http://www.britishwhaling.org/ * Howard, Mark, “Thomas Sturge and his fleet of South Sea whalers,” ''International Journal of Maritime History'', 27 (3) August 2015, 411-433.[http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/0843871415587249] * {{cite book |last=Jones |first=A.G.E. |title=Ships employed in the South Seas Trade 1775-1861 |year=1986 |publisher=Roebuck |location=Canberra |isbn=0909434301 }}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Struge, Thomas}} [[Category:1787 births]] [[Category:1866 deaths]] [[Category:Whaling firms]] [[Category:Whaling in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:English Quakers]] [[Category:People from South London]] [[Category:Exploration of Antarctica]] [[Category:Abolitionism]] [[Category:Cement]] [[Category:Railway lines]] [[Category:English philanthropists]] [[Category:British whalers]] [[Category:Companies based in the London Borough of Southwark]] [[Category:19th-century English businesspeople]] [[Category:History of Antarctica]] [[Category:British philanthropists]] [[Category:English philanthropists]] [[Category:Sealers]]

{{Infobox religious building | building_name = Vaduz Cathedral
{{lang|de|Kathedrale St. Florin in Vaduz}} {{de icon}} | infobox_width = | image = Vaduz Kathedrale St. Florin 01.jpg | image_size = | caption = | location = [[Vaduz]] | geo = {{coord|47.1362|N|9.5227|E|type:landmark_region:LI|display=title}} | religious_affiliation = [[Roman Catholic Church]] | rite = [[Roman Rite]] | municipality = | consecration_year = 1873 | status = [[Cathedral]] | functional_status = | heritage_designation = | leadership = Archbishop [[Wolfgang Haas]] | website = [http://www.erzbistum-vaduz.li/ www.erzbistum-vaduz.li] | architecture = yes | architect = Friedrich von Schmidt | architecture_type = [[church architecture|church]] | architecture_style = [[Gothic architecture|High Gothic]] | general_contractor = | facade_direction = [[West]] | groundbreaking = 1869 | year_completed = 1874 | construction_cost = | specifications = yes | capacity = | length = | width = | width_nave = | height_max = }} '''Vaduz Cathedral''', or '''Cathedral of St. Florin''' ([[German language|German]]: ''St. Florinskirche in Vaduz'' or ''Kathedrale St. Florin''), is a [[neo-Gothic]] church in [[Vaduz]], [[Liechtenstein]], and the center of the [[Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Vaduz]]. Originally a [[parish church]], it has held the status of cathedral since 1997. It was built in 1874 by [[Friedrich von Schmidt]] on the site of earlier medieval foundations. Its [[patron saint]] is [[Florinus of Remüs]] (Florin), a 9th-century saint of the [[Vinschgau Valley]]. The [[Archdiocese]] of [[Vaduz]] was erected by [[Pope John Paul II]] in the [[apostolic constitution]] ''Ad satius consulendum'' 2 December 1997. Before then it had been the Liechtenstein Deanery, a part of the [[Switzerland|Swiss]] [[Bishop of Chur|Diocese of Chur]]. The solemn public ceremony took place on December 12, 1997, in the parish church of Vaduz, which was then raised to the dignity of a [[cathedral]]. Prince [[Franz Joseph II, Prince of Liechtenstein|Franz Joseph II]] of Liechtenstein and his wife [[Countess Georgina von Wilczek|Princess Georgina]] were both buried in the cathedral in 1989. Princess [[Elisabeth von Gutmann|Elisabeth of Liechtenstein]] (1875-1947) was buried there too. ==Other burials== *[[Prince Karl Aloys of Liechtenstein]] (in the Fürstliche Gruft) *[[Princess Elisabeth of Urach]] (also in the Fürstliche Gruft) ==Image gallery== Vaduz Cathedral Interior.jpg|The nave and choir of the Vaduz Cathedral File:Vaduz Cathedral-interiors II.jpg|Portals and pipe organ ==See also== * [[Roman Catholicism in Liechtenstein]] ==External links== {{Commons}} * {{de icon}} [http://www.erzbistum-vaduz.li/Vaduz.htm Pfarrei St. Florin auf der Internetpräsenz des Erzbistums Vaduz] * {{de icon}} [https://web.archive.org/web/20080403034124/http://www.vaduz.li/kirche/kirchen.html Kirche St. Florin auf der Internetpräsenz der Gemeinde Vaduz] [[Category:Vaduz|Cathedral]] [[Category:Catholic Church in Liechtenstein]] [[Category:Roman Catholic cathedrals in Europe]] [[Category:Gothic Revival architecture in Liechtenstein]] [[Category:Gothic Revival church buildings]] [[Category:Roman Catholic churches completed in 1874]] [[Category:Roman Catholic cathedrals in Liechtenstein]] [[Category:Burial sites of the House of Urach]] {{Liechtenstein-stub}}
